Remind me again how many working-class people get to work in Hollywood? Except as carpenters I mean.But the movie's biggest flaw, by far, isn't the cast, not even the overall clumsiness in the dialog and some rather silly situations. It's the lopsided battle between good and evil, the biggest disease of modern horror. Bye Bye Man (I feel damn silly writing his name, I feel more cringe than fear, to be honest) is so utterly powerful, literally like a god, whereas the students are so hopelessly powerless and overwhelmed, unable to perform any magic tricks whatsoever, so that it's pretty obvious from the get-go that they have zero chance in winning this war. In fact, between the three of them they didn't even win a single battle against the boogeyman. Modern horror films are so drenched in nihilism i.e. hip pessimism/cynicism that almost 90% of them have "downer endings". This by now almost traditionalist zeal for ending films this way has lead to a level of predictability that's never existed in cinema before. Why would you expect a viewer to get involved in the protagonists' struggle if the struggle is doomed to failure nearly every time? This is one of the several key reasons why horror fans are getting increasingly bored with American horror films. Start giving the heroes a fighting chance and the audiences might be complaining less of being bored.Towards the end, when BB Man approaches Douglas Smith (1:25:30), I had a stark sense of déjà-vu with heavy doses of "Star Wars": Douglas Smith resembles Hayden Christensen and the boogeyman is a dead ringer for a Sith lord. It was a bizarre moment. Though not nearly as bizarre as the illogical behavior of Douglas's brother and his daughter in the final scenes. Or the fact that this young girl was brought along to a student party, around the beginning of the film, even allowed to roam unsupervised. What was that all about? Was she offered beer-bongs then?
Well what I can say about this movie this was the typical example how bad horror movie should look like.

reviews.review_title: I am shocked of the IMDb rate. READ ALL OF IT!
reviews.content: Just for once my girlfriend and I decided to go to a movie with an IMDb rating this low (at the moment 3.5). For us IMDb is everything, we really trust on the opinion of the crowd. We really love horror and thriller movie's. I can tell you one thing, this movie is GREAT! Once again I am shocked to see the IMDb rating. I think it's bullshit it got rated so low by some *prohibited word on here* who think they are "movie experts" and have nothing to do with their life. I mean what the *what two people do when making love*, "rating movie's" that's not even a real job. Go *love* yourself. And yes I am mad, because I feel great unfairness against the makers of this movie. They really did a great job! I understand there can be a different in taste. But as hard as I try to be objective: it is still a really good movie. But worst of all; how many (good) movie's did I skip through the years because of a low IMDb rating...Just because all of this, I took effort to google and find out how to write a review on here to warn you all (and yes, it is hard to find the button for writing a review here). Please go to the movie and let me know that I am not the only one and crazy. Please, my life is upside down now. I NEED TO KNOW. ~ don't think it ~ don't say it ~

Don't say it; don't think it – a piece of advice uttered and repeated ad nauseum by the year's newest batch of disposable teens in this year's newest disposable horror; The Bye Bye Man. Question: If I repeat the words "don't think it, don't say it" as if it were a mantra, aren't I still thinking about it? I, mean anyone who's been through a terrible breakup will probably tell you when you say "don't think about it," your mind automatically wonders back to one who broke your heart. Also, are the people cursed by this year's newest disposable apparition aware that "bye-bye, man," is a fairly common turn of phrase? So does that mean everyone who says that at any point in their life is affected by the curse or only after they've discovered it exists? The Bye Bye Man is the name of this year's newest disposable horror film apparition. He appears when you say his name, his influence spreads with every utterance and he can be challenged once you've become wise to his game. So he's basically a hybrid of Freddy Krueger, the Candyman and the "It" in It Follows (2014) only with a look and feel stolen from a Lab Rats music video. Truth be told, the setup does have possibilities. A minor character refers to him as a reaper so perhaps something salient could have been said about the specter of death and how it can warp our behavior. Or perhaps The Bye Bye Man could be a parable of forgotten history. Another minor character makes the point that once you bury the story, "It's like it never existed." The movie could have been an exploration of mass hysteria, a project exploring groupthink, exploring mental illness, exploring the never-ending march of timeIt could have explored a lot of things is what I'm saying.But no The Bye Bye Man is essentially about a group of university students who stumble onto a haunted nightstand and barely grasp its implications. We get our macho jock (Laviscount), our pretty and popular female lead (Bonas), our creepy outcast (Kanell) and our pale-faced protagonist (Smith) who fights his fate while wearing band t-shirts that are far too old for him. Veteran actresses Carrie-Anne Moss and Faye Dunaway also make appearances in contrived, unnecessary scenes that are there to point out the filmmakers didn't properly utilize their shooting schedule. Thus we're pretty much stuck with our fresh-faced meat-sacks for the duration of this film.And while we're stuck with them, our group of heroes seems to be hopelessly stuck in a plot that is actively working against them. They start the obligatory parade of clichés by having a housewarming séance. They then immediately fall into false frights, unexplained phenomena, and a second act investigation requiring one or more of them to rummage through library records. All the while, any chance to flesh out our characters is eschewed in favor of everyone yelling "who did you tell!" The only time we're offered a respite from the painfully expected and familiar is when we get heavily edited flashback scenes of the Bye Bye Man tormenting a reporter (Whannell) who got a little too nosy for his own good. These scenes approach the quality of mediocre dinner theater.At one point early in the film, Elliot yells from the other room "Let's watch something stupid," to his girlfriend who is distracted by haunting noise. We then cut to them sleeping. That in a nutshell is The Bye Bye Man. It's a lazy, boring and predictable movie that at times feels edited beyond comprehension. Don't think it, don't say it - Don't see it.

reviews.review_title: The Bye Bye Man resulted in me wanting to "Bye Bye" myself to death.
reviews.content: I should've known, all the evidence was there. First January weekend release, low budget horror, negative reviews, all the signs indicating that this was going to be terrible. I just didn't know it was going to be THIS atrocious. It revolves around a group of teenagers who rent a house, everything is great until one of them sees the name "The Bye Bye Man" etched onto some furniture. Unfortunately for that individual, you can't say or even think of the name otherwise he will come for you. A representation of how an idea can manifest the mind, metaphorically conveying the sins of our...oh who am I even kidding, it's just an old man in a cloak. The mythology behind "The Bye Bye Man", in retrospect, is quite stupid. Subconsciously you will always think about the name, so really if you ever see those words...you're pretty much done for. Adios. See you later! Keeping the above in mind, no thrills can effectively be produced because the characters are going to die anyway. You can't stop yourself thinking of something, 'Inception' taught us this! Regardless, this was utter rubbish. Aside from the promising opening sequence and Carrie-Anne Moss doing her best Trinity impression (*cough* lifeless *cough*) there was nothing original here. Just one or two jump scares and some kids rapidly going insane shouting "Don't say it! Don't think it!". The characters had as much development as the antagonist's name (hint: none) and the acting was truly awful, particularly Bonas. It was borderline TV movie standard. The "scares" were just loud noises or plastic stunt dolls unexpectedly getting demolished by an oncoming vehicle, that's it. They even CGI'd his skinless hell hound, badly may I just say. Wait, why does he even have one!? Who is "The Bye Bye Man"? Why is there a guy called Virgil? Did he seriously look up "The Bye Bye Man" on a search engine, in a library? Why am I wasting precious life watching this!? Urgh, I'm done. Uninteresting, unoriginal, unexciting and damn un-fricking-scary. I'm waving goodbye to this trash.

I don't know what to say, I've just saw it and i was amazed by how really bad it was (i know it was bad, but not like that!).The begging of the film is the same stereotype of every horror film (couple get a new house sorry a new HUNTED HOUSE), nevertheless i continued to watch it, and the more i did the more i felt terrible.There is nothing special about this film(same ideas,Same plot,same acting performance). I really felt bad for miss Dunaway, she started her career with great hits such as (Bonnie and Clyde, Chinatown, and Network) and then destroyed herself with terrible films such as (Mommie Dearest,supergirl and this SH#### one!) i'm pretty sure this film will battle (fifty shades darker) at the next Razzie ceremony. please stay away from this film don't watch it in cinema, buy it or even download it for free.

reviews.review_title: The worst horror movie I've seen in a theater!!!
reviews.content: I created an account just to write a review on this movie that's how angry I am that I paid money to see this piece of garbage. It was not scary at all. I've seen cartoon movies that were scarier. There wasn't even a typical jump scare in the whole movie. Ever who gives this movie a good rating clearly is involved with the movie itself. The movie doesn't even give us the satisfaction of a back story of the so called bye bye man. The writer of this movie should find another occupation and the movie studio who allows this movie to be made deserves the crappy response's that it's getting. So if you are bored and looking for a movie to go see then please do not waste your money on this one. I wouldn't even rent this movie for a dollar. Yes it is that bad!!!!

reviews.review_title: I went into this expecting exactly what I got
reviews.content: The idea of, 'dont say it dont speak it,' is cool. As is the way it goes about it.But the actual bye bye man and his dog were funny and there was no explanation of who or why. They looked like cheap Halloween costumes.The plot was all over the place and barely there. It was like they took a 10 page script idea and tried to make it fill out 50 pages. The ending was just. Why.

reviews.review_title: "The Bye Bye Man" becomes "The Buy Buy Man"...By Comittee
reviews.content: Cut from an "R" to a Pg-13, the Committee behind this Horror Movie Deserves Every Bad Review it has Attained, and it has Attained an Avalanche of Criticism as one of the Worst Big-Screen "Boogeyman" Films.These Critics Know that this is going to be a "Bomb" because it was Released in January and that Preludes Disaster, and Professional Critics all like to Think that Their a Special Breed, and will Mention this as "Insider" Knowledge. Too Cool for School.So the Piling On Begins. Virtually in Lock-Step the Bad Reviews Commence from Cooler than Cool, Hipper than Hip, In the Know Don'tcha Know Commentators. Let's Get Real.Most Horror Movies of this Type are Manufactured to Turn a Profit and if it's Art, that's a By-Product. This one is No Different. The Producers had Zero Faith in the Film. Took an Axe to it at the First Chance and Waited for the Money to Manifest. All Else is Secondary. "The Bye Bye Man" Doubled its Budget on Opening Day. The Movie is Slap-Dash and Haphazard, Barely Thought-Out and Feels Amateurish at times. You could Say that about 95% of the Low-Budget Genre Releases. A Great Number go Straight to Video. This one isn't much Better or Worse than the Lot of Them.It's Not as Bad as its Reviews would Suggest and Really Not Very Good. It's Exactly what One would Expect. There are a Few Chills and some Scenes Look Great while other Scenes Look Awful. The Story is the Weakest Element because there is Very Little Exposition in what Ultimately Amounts to Viewer Indifference as the Film Unfolds.Worth a Watch for Die-Hard Horror Fans with Low Expectations. It's a Mess but What Else is New in Hollywood Horror Town? People made this Profitable so the People (including Critics) can't Complain Unless They are Complaining about the Movie Going Public as much as the Movie Makers.

Ludicrous story. Dialogue that resembles a group of kids "pretending" to play "Scary Movie" (for those of us who remember when kids used to play- pretend. A mish-mash of all the insipid supernatural clichés that have riddled teen-horror flicks for the past decade or so. Poor Faye Dunaway collects a check for a cameo that reduces her legendary skills to that of an acting student at their first audition. Enjoy.

This was a good, fun horror! The acting was fine, and the story was interesting. For a horror it was nicely original, the twisty turny moments cleverly done, kept me interested and tense in all the right places. If you like horror, with a psychological aspect, give it a go, I reckon it's well worth it.

reviews.review_title: Don't see it, don't buy it, don't see it, don't but it
reviews.content: If you know he exists, he will come for you next, as you speak or even think his name. He defies the laws of physics, drives his victims mad, and has been spotted in old photographs, observing ominously. To make a long story short: Doug Jones reprises his role as Slender Man (Always Watching: A Marble Hornets Story) albeit with a far sillier name and an actual face to show. I wish I could say that that's the only film The Bye Bye Man derives ideas from, without any aspiration to subvert or freshen them up, but here we are.On top of its cookie-cutter script and remedial horror film tactics (Do I even need to say the word "jump scare"?), the film offers porno-level performances and characters that explain to each other who they are in a manner that's, well, whatever the antonym of the word "seamless" is. We mainly follow a trio of youngsters (Douglas Smith, Lucien Laviscount and Cressida Bones) who stumble upon the origins of an evil entity known as The Bye Bye Man after one of them develops an inexplicable cough and weird scribblings are found. Again, totally not a Slender Man movie.What we (and the protagonists) soon learn is that The Bye Bye Man has influenced the evil of mankind for several decades, as there are several documented cases where teenagers have committed mass murders and left notes behind reading "The Bye Bye Man made me do it". Even though we finally have an explanation for all the shootings and hate crimes that have taken place in recent memory, provided I've understood the premise of this film correctly, I am also to understand that The Bye Bye Man has only existed since the 1960's. So I guess he wasn't around during The Holocaust or the Dark Ages and cannot be blamed for all of the world's horrors. Just a couple.Also in on the fun are Carrie-Anne Moss as a generic hard-ass cop (who is astoundingly quick to buy into the main characters' "It wasn't me, it was the tall ghost dude" routine) and Faye Dunaway as Cameo #2. At least these two are watchable, which is more than I can say for some of the lesser-known actors. I can recommend watching Jeremy Jahns' review of this film (even as I've come to regard him as more of a "dude who loves movies" than an educated critic like Mike Stoklasa or Adam Johnston), in which he includes an anecdote about how he watched it at a special screening hosted by the cast and crew, and how the viewers would laugh whenever Cressida Bones said or did anything - whilst she was most likely in the theatre with them, mind you. Ouch.In other areas, the film is similarly amateurish, to the point where I must question if it truly belongs on the big screen and not on the same hard drive as some of the embarrassing student films I made in 2013 before I became (relatively) more careful with what I upload to YouTube. I suppose it technically has better sound, visual effects and editing than that, but the cinematography and writing are pretty down there.Still, the film could have worked in the hands of someone else, or perhaps even these same people if the budget wasn't so low. I liked the shot where Doug Jones' character appears as a silent silhouette in the main character's bedroom (even if a mandatory pop scare kills its effect) and I'd love to see the repulsive hound that occasionally turns up, done with better CGI.

I typed in horror movies on Netflix and the title and graphic stuck out, so I hit play. I was hoping for some creepy jump scares and what I got was mostly blah and not scary at all. This is pretty predictable and has been done before in other horror movies. What saves this from being terrible is the acting isn't bad for this type of movie, and that is what saves this from being a total slog. Carrie Anne Moss makes a surprise appearance in this as a police detective and she saves the movie just when you might be ready to give up. I usually don't rate B-movies very high, so a four is a decent score. If you don't mind wasting 90 minutes of your life and you generally like horror movie this is will fit somewhere in a niche.4/10.

Watched with a couple of friends and had a great time.
It's In the:"so bad that it's awesome category"

This movie is about John, Sasha and Elliott (Sasha and Elliott are a couple) who decide to live off campus in an old house. The female of the group starts hearing a coin being tossed and strange noises. After they fix the place up, they have a party, after which they conduct a seance with Kim, who has physic abilities. During the seance, she feels like something is coming and Elliott who is skeptical blurts out "The Bye Bye Man" and the candle blows out. It kind of reminds me of the movie "the Ring" or "Candyman". I like horror movies that don't depend on gore or sex to sell the plot. That's not scary, I want to be startled or be tempted to cover my eyes. The thought that someone is waiting around the corner, that's what gets you. There were a couple of really good scares in this movie and the audience seemed to jump more than once.

reviews.review_title: So glad I skip this movie from theaters but regret renting it
reviews.content: This movie suck so bad. It's boring like so boring that I almost feel like falling asleep. The acting suck, the story is terrible, poorly done C.G.I, terrible writing and it's not even scary. This feel like a IT (1990) rip off (I'm not saying the 2017 one because it didn't came out when this was release). I kinda hate it even since it was release but I didn't see it in theaters. I wish I didn't rent it my god that's a big mistake. Don't watch this movie. Don't think this movie and Don't say this movie because it suck.

reviews.review_title: Not much of an horror i'd say a thriller
reviews.content: I have wanted to watch this for ages and I wish I didn't... I didn't go with high expectations after reading the reviews & it's a good job I didn't have high expectations. The acting was bad I didn't get the 'Horror' vibe from no where in the film it felt more like a thriller to me with a creepy hooded guy & his dog coming into it now and again

reviews.review_title: A study of mental illness, a superior horror film, or both?
reviews.content: Throughout "The Bye Bye Man", I often thought that what I was watching could be construed as a powerful statement on the tragedy of mental illness. Watching his face contort with the inner turmoil of one whose suffering is too much to bear, but who cannot share it with another soul, Douglas Wilson turns in what, in another movie, could be an Academy Award winning performance of a man with schizophrenia.He is repeatedly victim of apparent hallucinations, all of which seem to be leading him toward senseless violence. Hurting people he loves, and perhaps, more likely, hurting himself.This will be familiar to anyone who has ever known someone who suffers from mental illness. Wilson's portrayal is close to heartbreaking.I was surprised that "The Bye Bye Man" never opens the door to that kind of ambiguity, never suggesting that the spectres within it could be evidence of a fractured mind, and not supernatural in origin.What we have here, nevertheless, is a superior horror movie with a stand-out performance in the lead. It never scared me very much, but it involved me throughout, and, for once, it was not predictable.For the life of me, I just cannot fathom its woeful 4.3 rating on this very website. Clearly something went very wrong for most viewers of "The Bye Bye Man", and I can't guess what.

Incredibly bad movie. Bad acting and the story could have been so much better than it was. I thought it was a bit messy. The lines were too unnatural. When someone breaks into your home, the question is not "who are you?" in a calm way, but "get the hell out !!" . Was also a lot of mistakes in the movie... it's simply a low budget movie... The only reason I went to so this film in theaters was due to the good feedback some people on IMDb had written. If you are in doubt then wait until it comes out on DVD / Netflix. it's not worth seeing it in theaters, select a different movie.

reviews.review_title: You Know This Movie Was Bad When You Have To Reset Your IMDb Password To Write A Review
reviews.content: I'm sorry but, what? Okay, the film had potential...LOTS OF IT! A story about this "thing" called, The Bye Bye Man, that whenever you think or say it's name it gets closer and closer to you to kill you, and the fact that it's hard to not think about something you already know of, that can be pretty scary. HOWEVER, this movie did not execute it well! My first issue was, THE ACTING!!!!!! The only person I could stand was Elliot. Elliot's girlfriend was too much...like it felt like she thought she was in like a high school play or something. It just got to the point where I literally said to myself, "Can they please stop giving this girl lines..." Everyone else is tolerable. Just...that girl...The writing was pretty awful too! Where's the back story of The Bye Bye Man??? Why whenever he's near you hear coins dropping and hear a train coming...who is this dude? What is he? Where did he come from? Who, what, when, where, and how...nothing made sense. The only "back story" we actually got was of a writer who really was of no real importance at all...Now, did this movie have scary parts, I mean...sure. But every time something scary would happen, you're pulled back out with either bad acting or bad direction. I hate seeing movies with potential, go to waste...like this movie was just so bad...Should you watch this, I mean...yes/no. If you're like SUPER BORED, on a road trip trying to pass time, or something along those lines, sure watch this. If you want a film you can enjoy and be scared by, just ignore this movie..

I saw "The Bye Bye Man", Douglas Smith-Miss Sloane, Ouija; Cressida Bonas-This is her first movie but she was in Doctor Thorne_tv; Lucien Laviscount-Scream Queens_tv, Honeytrap and Doug Jones-The Strain_tv, Falling Skies_tv.This is a dud of a horror movie. As you can see by the actors listed above, they are not household names. The only good thing about it is there are a couple of good cameos; I remember seeing Cleo King, Carrie- Anne Moss and Faye Dunaway-Yes, I said Faye Dunaway! The plot goes like this; 3 college kids move into a house off campus and unbeknownst to the trio, the house has a secret. It seems that a reporter had been doing some research on a teenager that had went on a killing spree, saying that the Bye Bye Man made him do it. Legend of the Bye Bye Man goes that if you say his name or even hear it, then you are his next target. The reporter is next and then the college kids. What happens when you are BBM's target? You kill anyone that has said or heard the name and then you kill yourself. The Bye Bye Man does not actually do anything! All he does is make people see things that are not there! He doesn't physically do anything! Douglas, Cressida and Lucien are the college kids and Doug is the Bye Bye Man. Oh yeah, people keep repeating the phrase, 'Don't say it! Don't think it!' a lot. I guess it's supposed to make the Bye Bye Man seem scarier or something. It's rated "PG-13" for terror, violence, bloody images, language, teen drinking and sexual content-including partial nudity-and has a running time of 1 hour & 36 minutes. I wouldn't buy it on DVD. I wouldn't rent it either. Avoid this one in the theaters. If you really must see it then I would wait until it comes to cable TV.

reviews.review_title: Not the worst, not the best.
reviews.content:
For a Netflix watch while convalescing, it was an okay film, but I wouldn't have wanted to pay movie ticket prices to see this.It was...okay. I didn't think the acting was as bad as some people here do. It could have been better (always), but it wasn't the worst I've seen by far.My main frustration is the hint of a greater mythology that's never explored! And after finding out that this was supposedly based on a chapter from a book about urban legends, and reading the legend, I really, really wish the movie makers had gone into more details about everything!Instead, there were just some references and appearances about possible connections to something more interesting, while we watched three people's insecurities about relationships get the better of them.Questions that I wanted answered in the movie:-- What was the deal with the train?
-- What was the deal with the clutter around the train track?
-- Where did all this begin?
-- Why didn't he burn the end table instead of just tossing it into the woods?
-- What was the dog? WAS it a dog?
-- Was it all in their heads? Or was the Man real?
-- Why does his name make people go nuts and kill their loved ones and themselves?
-- What was the deal with the coins? Why couldn't they stay on solid surfaces like desks and in drawers, but didn't fall through floors?
-- Why was Trinity in this? Why was Faye Dunaway??On and on and on.There was a really, really cool story that could have been explored here, and I'm very disappointed that it wasn't. :/

reviews.review_title: Don't Watch It, Don't Tweet About It!
reviews.content: So many good ideas in the world, how did none of them end up here...Bad acting, bad dialogue, bad script, bad effects, bad overbites (faye Dunaway), bad baddie - you get the idea.There was a kernel of something here, but it got lost long before shooting started and no one had the guts to just say - Bye Bye (i had to do it).

reviews.review_title: Well... the finest Wisconsin-set horror movie ever made...
reviews.content: I'm pretty sure that the makers of "The Bye Bye Man" were trying to make a horror franchise akin to the "Nightmare on Elm Street" movies, but the results are really not all that successful. For starters, the evil force in this particular movie hardly makes any appearances, believe it or not. Most of the horror instead comes from the various characters having hallucinations. While I guess this could have been a successful approach, it doesn't work here. After the opening scene depicting a (small scale) rampage in the past, the movie for the next fifty or so minutes can't come up with anything that is all that terrifying, at least if you don't count the second flashback that happens. The so-called scary stuff that happens in this first (slow) half of the movie is just people having mild hallucination - hardly terrifying, if you ask me. Although the second half of the movie does start to try and deliver the goods (it really pushes its PG-13 rating, by the way), it's still not all that involving, one reason being that there is no real explanation as to how The Bye Bye Man originated and why he does what he does. In the end, the movie is simply unsatisfying in any angle you can think of. Let's hope this franchise wannabe doesn't spawn any sequels.

The Bye Bye ManBeing haunted in the 1960s wasn't as scary as today because their SPFX make-up sucked.Luckily, the majority of this horror movie occurs in present-day.Elliot (Douglas Smith), his girlfriend (Cressida Bonas) and their friend (Lucien Laviscount) rent out an old house where a homicidal rampage played out in 1969.During a home séance an enigmatic entity, The Bye Bye Man (Doug Jones), emerges from limbo and begins driving the friends insane with hallucinations of infidelity, all because they said his name. With help from the only survivor of the massacre (Faye Dunaway), Elliot sets out to stop Bye Bye.Badly acted in both eras by actors who don't deserve the title, this inept adaptation of an obscure work of crypto-fiction is amateurish at best - the villain is derivative and the scares are nonexistent. Besides, monsters wouldn't be so sensitive about their names if they weren't so dumb sounding. Red Lightvidiotreviews.blogspot.ca

I though the summary was interesting enough to warrant a watch. 20 minutes in and the coin flipping and hallucinations just became annoying. This Bye Bye man was not fully developed. His presence wasn't very strong which made the plot a bit loose and ill formed. The movie was really safe, no real climax, no real solution. The plot nor the characters evolved. A lot more could have been done with the characters. The emphasis of this movie was on The Bye Bye man but seemed to focus more on the main character Elliot's struggle to beat this thing who had little screen presence.The actors were all great.For a horror movie there weren't any scary scenes that i could think of and the cgi hound really ticked me off. It wasnt realistic at all and made The Bye Bye man a bit laughable . I'm sure they could have created a more realistic hound.I will say the concept of this dark, powerful, supernatural power causing people to murder is a great idea and feels relevant to the nonsensical murder suicides that we see today.

reviews.review_title: Bland, boring and one of the stupidest story lines you'll ever see
reviews.content: A PG-13 rating for a horror movie is possibly the stupidest thing there is. What is the point, honestly? It's basically saying our intention is to scare you, but we are going to handicap ourselves in the process and likely fail for this reason. And shock horror, 'The Bye Bye Man' is one of the tamest horror movies out there. Not only is the action that does occur either very bland or happens off-screen, even then there's barely any of it. About 45 minutes into the film I was asking myself why exactly I was supposed to be a afraid of this creature considering it hasn't actually done anything yet (other than confuse a few teenagers about what they were actually seeing).Every flaw that modern horror movies tend to have is evident in some respect in this film. The characters are completely generic, unlikeable and unrelatable. The frights (though to be fair there were very few of them) are simply jump-scares which often have little to do with the story at hand. The biggest annoyance for me though was the implausibility. Now to be fair, very few horror movies don't have any implausibility, it's kind of a given. But when your story is as far-fetched and contrived as it is in the 'The Bye Bye Man', you have to wonder what the point is. How anyone could be made to feel uneasy about a subject as completely illogical as this I will never know.There's really not a lot of good things to say about this film. It achieves in absolutely no area. The fact that this film made it to cinemas is beyond me. Even with today's incredibly low standards of horror movies, 'The Bye Bye Man' is terrible.

seems most horror films these days save their best stuff not for last, it's always the opening that hooks you and it's always that scene where they put their best foot forward i.e. The Bye Bye Man. A suit and tie guy pulls up the driveway, gets out and throws wild accusations at a woman we are not introduced too but who cares since he offs her and everyone else that crosses his path, a psycho in dire need of his medication or is it the extreme paranoia that these people called out the 'bye bye man's' name that somehow triggers the utmost evil in common folk to execute and cause great bodily harm. It's a horror film so I would expect all the ills of society to come out and play, unfortunately the film tires quickly leaving me wanting much much more. The main characters are not fully defined and have the personality of warped wallpaper; granted they summon this evil spirit that resembles the grim reaper from Bill & Ted's Bogus Journey, twenty minutes later. There is a lot of drama between the roommates and at this point I wanted to put my hands through the screen and choke the life out of all them. A few scares does not a film make. Bye Bye, man.

I know that I can't take no more It ain't no lie I wanna see you out that door Baby, bye, bye, bye...OK, was it so bad that I had to do the N'SYNC reference for it? Maybe. I definitely have seen better.It's a little dumb and a lot corny, which makes for a bad combo.It tries to amp up the crazy in these ghost horror films and only ends up coming off crazy by doing so.It does start off just right. doing everything we were hoping the whole movie was going to be, just an intense craziness, that makes you go wow, with this flash back about how this ghost effected peoples lives in the 1960s.Then we come to modern times, and the movie starts to suck as we get to know three college age teenagers and their encounter with a ghost who when you say his name, starts you on this path of instantly, and like a chain letter if you mention this ghost to anyone they will start to feel the burn and nothing can stop him until you are dead.The Bye Bye Man himself was not a bad concept, but trying to fully pull off can be difficult as this movie proves.It's apart of that genre of ghost tales where it's about what goes bump in the night and how that jumps you out of your seat, which it didn't. It gets you with the superficial something is in the corner fright that anyone who paid to see the movie would want to experience, but it does not take long to get use to the Bye Bye man, and then what? The insanity that they are trying to pull of was funny, but not that impressive.http://cinemagardens.com

Ok so, a lot of 1 star reviews. I genuinely enjoyed this. The actress who played the girlfriend though is easily one of the worst actors I've ever seen. Thankfully she didn't have a huge part and didn't completely ruin it. Other than that, this is a solid movie. It isn't too slow, and it peaks curiosity very early on. Let's just say I didn't find myself perusing my meme page while watching. It gives just enough glimpses of what the bye bye man looks like, without giving it away right up front. I'm not a fan of when the monster/demon/ghost etc are revealed fully right off the bat. You had to pay attention and actually what is happening to the characters and why. I can kind of understand a bad review if you prefer everything just be laid out for you. I like the ones where you have to wonder a little. It wasn't painfully predictable either. I mean, as far as horror movies go, people lost their minds over the Paranormal Activity movies (which honestly still blows my mind). But this is the kind of movie i feel would do well with a sequel. There's enough story to be further explained as well as enough expectation that the story isn't over.
2/10 - I was not into this one at all - acting and storyline were subpar

reviews.review_title: The Bye Bye Man is a terrible horror film with literally no jump scares,pathetic screenplay and flawed direction.One of the Worst films of all time
reviews.content: The Bye Bye Man (2017): I have a strong belief that most of the time the horror movies which release in January will fail to impress.Last year we have got The Forest and The Boy which are quite disappointing.This year The Bye Bye Man is the first wide released horror film.So how is it?Plot:When three college students Elliot (Douglas Smith), John (Lucien Laviscount) and Elliot's current girlfriend, Sasha (Cressida Bonas) move into an old house off campus, they unwittingly unleash a supernatural entity known as The Bye Bye Man, who comes to prey upon them once they discover his name. The friends must try to save each other, all the while keeping The Bye Bye Man's existence a secret to save others from the same deadly fate.Plus Points:1)First 10 minutes: The movie started interestingly with a person going on a killing spree those who know some mysterious name.It raised hopes on film.Minus Points:1)No scary scenes,Terrible Screenplay and Flawed Direction: Still I couldn't know the reason how this movie got a theatrical release.Director Stacy Title failed in every aspect of making a horror film.There is not even a single scary scene even when they tried lot of jump scares.Mystery element is dragged beyond the limit and that too shown in a pathetic way.The movie is terribly staged and poorly edited. Literally, scenes don't match up, with action being cut off and having nothing in common with the next sequence. It's odd.It's mainly run-of-the-mill jump scares and predictable haunted-house shtick that brings absolutely nothing new to the genre.Its a common act that we make fun on horror films while watching with friends but while watching The Bye Bye Man,I made fun remarks even watching it alone.So,The Bye Bye Man is a terrible horror film with literally no jump scares,pathetic screenplay and flawed direction.One of the Worst films of all timeAs referred in film, Don't Think It Don't Say it....I would add Don't watch it too..My rating 3.5/10

reviews.review_title: Ignore the haters. It's actually quite a good film.
reviews.content:
Unsure why so many people are putting ridiculously low scores and saying worst film ever. That's just pathetic.
It's not the best film ever but it is well shot and acted. Quite an Interesting Freddy Krueger type entity. And enjoyed how it messes with the people's minds and made them imagine things.
The possibilities of further films and storylines are welcome.I just wish it had more blood and gore as was kinda lacking with that.Ignore the haters. Who all seemingly have a real chip on their shoulders about this film for some reason!? Far far worse films about for sure.

The Bye Bye Man, once supposed to come in September of 2016; There's a reason it's been once pushed to December, and now to January. The Bye Bye Man lingers so heavily to the point of where many of it's elements make it simply fall apart.We pretty much follow the story of Elliot, Sasha, and John, three college students who rent a home for themselves, only to be provoked by The Bye Bye man, after the past comes to haunt them, as part of the house they've rented. First off, really, if you're looking for a horror film that breaks down the whole origin of this entity, by no means will you get it. The Bye Bye Man / entities' origin, and reasoning behind all of the events it causes is truly never explained in the film, honestly coming off as an unexplained collection of scares, and movie fillings toward the characters. Throughout this entire movie, the characters all constantly get into ordeals with the entity, only giving the audience more of a want / wonderment toward the entity himself, only to be let down when the whole situation of the entity is never explained; The entire movie centers around this Bye Bye Man, and in the end, he, nor his doings and origins is never explained, and left out completely. Throughout the film, we get the characters figuring out pieces to the entities' puzzle, honestly the typical, and cliché "Old / dead document that can't be found anywhere else until now" gimmick seen in many, many other horror films. The characters all search, and find ways to stop temporarily, and prevent shortly the entity from provoking them, but really that's just about it. Time, after time until another character just randomly dies from this entity, these characters are all running around solving pieces of this entity, for what seems to be fill time; Absolutely no reasoning, really. Overall, really just a ton of, in the end, pointless doings toward an entity the film is entirely revolved around, yet overall never explains, nor goes in depth with such entity / entities to even begin with, rendering pointless, truly. Continuing, the acting in this movie was honestly a split. The character of Sasha honestly didn't fully live up to emotional showings, overall at a good chunk of lines sounding flat, and not truly in the zone of what specific scenes called for, the actor of Elliot, and John, surprisingly, however pulled a solid job with such emotions, and overall acting toward their situations. Moving even further, the films' displaying of events. There were parts where a character gets shot, or injured, and that character would sit, and absolutely no blood would be shown. There would be parts too reliant on CGI, coming off cheap looking, and blatantly fake, and out of place looking, for example a scare tactic that looked so out of proportion, it left a good amount of the audience in complete confusion. And as said before, there'd be happenings where the audience has no idea what to make of due to a major lack of information on the entity, example being his doings, and actions toward the characters.In conclusion, this films' plot, story-line, and in-depth execution was extremely flat, and extremely incoherent when given deep thought. The Bye Bye man, and other entities that built this films' hype up was shown, but no background prevailed, and overall would seem as if these entities were just thrown in for scare tactics, and story fillings. The story executed in a cliché, and overly done matter that didn't differentiate itself from what's been done before, the characters, for the most part did pointless actions that amounted to nothing story / plot changing with the exception of some scenes; Which is one of the very few things that can be said. And overall the CGI, and some shots shown looked quite off, and questionable that lead to an audience- wide reaction. To wrap things up, there's a reason, again this was pushed quite a few times. The Bye Bye Man, overall had extremely low redeeming qualities such as a twist or two, but overall amounted to nothing, quite literally, and even more so executed some of the most pointless actions that lead to, once again, nothing. I'd recommend seeing this when it's out of the theaters, The Bye Bye Man wasn't worth the push back wait, overall, and was a disappointing start to horrors' 2017.

there is a book called the Bye Bye Man and I read it. It is very weird and strange and scary. I recommend you read the book first, then you will appreciate the movie more. It will creep you out. I wish they would make more horror movies out of creepy books like these. For instance I wish they would make movies from Peter Straub's books. They are very scary.

I was drawn to write this review by the weird, skewed reviews of others here. Of course, tastes are highly subjective, but the scathing, "worst movie ever" type comments here are just ridiculous.Is Bye Bye Man a brilliant, must-see horror? No, not at all. Is the acting Oscar-worthy? No, but I've seen plenty worse. Actually, it didn't bother me. Someone here mentioned things not making sense. What? I'm not sure. It was all pretty straightforward, supernatural premise aside. I found the first quarter to be genuinely creepy and well-paced. Once we know what's going on, it goes a bit silly. But that's almost the recipe for these kinds of movies.I gave it a solid 6 because it entertained me (on the particular night, and in the particular mood, I watched it.) I've watched countless horror movies and I can be a snob when I want to. I usually have no time for the CGI-laden, cliché-ridden fare that passes for horror these days. Bye Bye Man, while certainly approaching that, had just barely enough of something interesting to make it better than many. It's no masterpiece, but it also isn't the 1-star material that others here will have you believe. I wonder how many Andy Milligan films they've seen?

reviews.review_title: Don't think it, don't say it
reviews.content: The Bye-Bye Man was a decent movie. I almost didn't watch it because of the bad reviews, but I'd figure I'd give it a try, and I'm glad I did! It was creepy and kept me on the edge of my seat throughout the movie. I would recommend seeing this if you love creepy, exciting movies!

SpoilersBasic premise makes no sense. The Bye Bye Man tricks you into killing your family and friends, but to defeat him you have to kill your family and friends. HUH? So either way he gets what he wants. He should let people live so that they say his name until everyone in the world says his name... then trick them into killing everyone. So the basic core makes no sense and all the rest is typical nonsense. Why are you forced to say his name if he can do that why not force everyone in the world to say his name. Why doesn't he chop up the desk and burn it. If he can control it sometimes and not other times isn't that just for plot convenience? I recommend you skip this movie even with the low standards horror I generally find acceptable for horror movies this is too silly.

My main issue with this movie is that there is no creativity in the movie. Everything has been done already dozens of times in the past. (I am thinking of movies like Candyman, Sinister 1 & 2, It follows and so many more...). It even uses almost the same method as Candyman for evil to appear. It made also think a few times to the Final destination franchise where the protagonists are hunted by Death (same actor as the Candyman by the way.) What bothered me in this movie is how unbelievable certain events were. For example the librarian immediately starts actively cooperating, the brother who takes his little kid with him (can anyone be so irresponsible?) If it would have been the first with this plot I would give it a 7 but now 6 is more than sufficient for this movie...

reviews.review_title: Just say goodbye to the Bye Bye Man.
reviews.content: Before I get into anything I need to say that I think there was a good idea for this movie. There is the hint of a good movie trying to get out of it. But the movie we got was so inept and so bad that whatever chance it had died an early and forgotten death. In other movies where there's a supernatural kind of killer there is always a backstory. There's a reason for the killer to be so crazy. Not here. We're told of a guy that killed a bunch of people for speaking the name of this entity. That's it. That's all the backstory we get. Well, not exactly. There's a librarian who later on is only there to provide exposition. In a less clunky movie they would have found a better way to provide this to the audience. A bunch of college students move into this house because it's close to campus, it's cheap and they want to live together. They find an old nightstand and in the drawer is written over and over again the lines don't think of it, don't speak of it over and over again. Ripping that paper away we see the title carved into the drawer. It had to be because otherwise there literally would be no story.And once the name is spoken weird things start to happen and that's basically the movie from then on. It's not coherent as to what is happening, it's just stuff. The man that killed the people at the beginning is just there with no real connection to the supernatural killer. At no point is this scary or thrilling or anything other than you want these kids to die because they're so annoying. This is one of the best examples of a January movie. It came out after the holidays. It's dumped into theaters because they need to show something. It's a PG-13 movie to get all the kids to go see it. And it's just something to be avoided.

This movie is really not that scary. It had me jumped only once. The idea of this movie is good, but the vision how it shows is not. If you are looking for a movie just to waste some time, this is it! It won´t leave you traumatized :D

reviews.review_title: He who should not be named
reviews.content: My first impression of the movie premise was that it was going to be like the movie "the ring" I was really excited by the opening scene, where a man is hunting down people who say "the name".Otherwise, besides moments of brilliant acting, I thought the movie was pretty average. It wasn't terrible or the best, it was average. Another review on IMDB said that they were reminded of a horror movie parody and I agree.

Manny's Movie Musings: "The Bye Bye Man" is a mediocre horror movie about a malevolent spirit whose name must not be mentioned, or else he'll become more powerful and he will eventually kill anyone who utters his name. An extremely intense, violent and shocking opening sequence sets the bar very high, but it's only a tease, as the rest of the movie is a disappointment from that point. The stupid decisions the victims make, the silly excuses the story makes to get the parents out of the way, and the cheap scares all contribute to making this movie forgettable. In the trailer, it is mentioned that the spirit's name must not be saidhe must not even be thought of. Well, "The Bye Bye Man" is a movie that will soon be lost in the vast ocean of horror movies that failed to live up to their hype; a title that no one will ever utter nor remember.Mannysmemorablemoviemoments

Besides being a shameless ripoff of the Candyman franchise, Bye Bye Man can only be described as a movie that's a failed attempt to create a new horror character and series. Maybe that's why the movie feels incomplete. It starts something new, but never follows up. The new horror character doesn't carry the movie like other horror icons do. The premise is interesting for a few moments, but strange character choises and atrocious acting ruin everything that otherwise might have lead to sequels.The lack of an interesting character, the lack of background, ineffective scares make this into something completely forgettable. Say bye bye to The Bye Bye Man.

reviews.review_title: Don't think it! Don't say it! Just watch it!
reviews.content: There's nothing major difference with this and the regular horror flicks, except the internal structure of the tale. For that alone, it is worth a watch. Because they have used it the better way, yet the familiarity gives out everything to its viewers. So sad that you could predict the entire film, despite their best effort to turn it around. The good news is, if you are not a horror film fan, you possibly would enjoy it. But those who love and watch horror films regularly would find it somewhat a waste of time. I was the first one, and I thought it was better than some of the recent big names from the same genre.Yeah, looks a mix of plenty of films. It was somewhat like 'It Follows', but less complicated. Easy to follow the characters and the story. Though from the beginning itself, it was very intentional. A decent cast and the filmmaking. It could be scary for some viewers, but I found a little edgy and well paced narration. But sadly it did not miss any of the usual horror flick formula. One of the most overused, not just in this film, but any horror films is that those film character interviewing the one of the survivours from the past. So if you don't mind such common usage, it is an acceptable film.6/10

This movie is amazing in term of direction and first scene was way too good with continuous 5 minute shot and I am amazed to see what people these days are seeing in movies, This movie is great! I am not big fan of horror movies but, after watching this i Can there are lots of dark elements like the hound, Bye bye man itself mystery and almost everything.. I definitely want a part II. I don't know why people hated it but, this movie is pure gem with great acting and story line. Love to see what will happened next. I think after james wan I can proudly say this director is next BIG THING. wow, Just watch it think some stupid rating can bring this movie down because it awesome.. Better then some so called famous movies like split, the witch etc.

reviews.review_title: Don't say It. Don't think about this film
reviews.content: The movie isn't great. The effects early on are so so poor. Luckily they do get better later on. When we see the actual monster it's not scary at all. CGI is poor. I find the middle of this movie to be okay however its not scary at all. The best thing about this movie is the tag line.

reviews.review_title: Bad title, silly name, but get past that and give it a shot
reviews.content: I would ignore the bad reviews, and the low rating, and give it a shot. I guess most people these days don't understand the concept of a good horror movie. I almost passed because of the silly title, but I was entertained throughout.

reviews.review_title: Not sure why the low ratings....
reviews.content:
My FIRST REVIEW because I feel bad for this flick!!!
This just popped up on my Netflix and read the IMDB reviews so I wouldn't waste my time if it really truly sucked. I read some of the more elaborate detailed reviews and thought I would give it a good 10 minutes before saying NEXT. I enjoyed it!!!If you like the older horror genre of Jeepers Creepers, the Ring, The Grudge, Hush, 6th Sense etc - you will enjoy this flick. I appreciated the fact that there wasn't over the top partying, random sex and drugs. Something that is PG clean but rated PG13 for the scare thrills. Oh! I suppose I could compare this to Birdbox and/or Quiet Place.If you want Saw or Hostel than this flick is NOT for you

reviews.review_title: Not that good but also, not that bad!
reviews.content:
Of course the movie is not perfect! There is some trouble with the performances, is very predictable and not particularly scary. However the story that it tell us is good and well thought. You want to know who is this man, what is all the mistery about and it plays tricks with your mind (only if you don't predict them). 
Althought the bad reviews I suggest it.

reviews.review_title: What do you think im a flashlight?
reviews.content: Very poorly acted, edited, and directed horror movie that has more funny parts then scary.

reviews.review_title: Movie is good, don't be a door knob!
reviews.content: The movie is ok for a horror movie. You won't get blown up or mega scared, they put or their hopes for this movie is the story, because acting wasn't that great, and most of times the movie wasn't scary at all.

I always like watching a good scary horror, most horrors are extremely obvious and watching a film when you know what happens next is not fun, so when I sat down to watch this I checked the reviews all of which except a few are all completely WRONG. This film I found is one of the best horrors I have watched in quite a few years please remember R.Ts do not always get it right, I am sure they get the wrong reviewers to watch the wrong films hence wrongly reviewing what is actually a very good film.

reviews.review_title: The tagline is better than the movie
reviews.content:
The tagline is better and more interesting than the movie.
The premise is interesting but with bad effects, less than mediocre dialogue and acting - the movie ends up going into the hall of shame.If you want to watch a movie where you can smell the jumpscares a mile away, then fine, watch this. There is literally no other reason to.

I'm guessing that the idea for this film looked and sounded really great on paper. But then the toughest part is turning it into a film that's where it went wrong, the story becomes a mess with some scenes that have more of a spoof feel than a thriller/horror.A group of friends hold a spiritual night in their new place and strange things begin to happen to them, one by one they all start to suffer from the bye bye man.The film had so much potential yet watching this you will feel let down as if they rushed the production and skipped pages of the script that would of made a lot more sense, Overall it's a waste of a great idea.

reviews.review_title: 6/10 is not as bad as the reviews says
reviews.content: This is not the best movie of horror of all time, but is a different horror flick from the traditional flicks nowadays. I don't understand why so much hate around this movie, I think the Movie deserves a 6/10, it has good story and original story, the movie has some good moments, and the ending is OK. The mystery behind the first 10 min of movie are good because they make you want to keep seeing just to know what is actually happening. I wanted to review this movie because despite the awful reviews I decided to give an opportunity, and it is good to see with your girlfriend. I repeat this is not the best movie or is not even a good movie, but is not that bad as the reviews are saying. Don't expect to much, but is very watchable.

reviews.review_title: Don't waste your money or time
reviews.content: I never really write reviews, but I feel I have to warn fellow horror fans about this movie. It is unfortunately a complete waste of money. There a lot of problems with this film, but I'll point out the worst in my opinion:1. It actually starts pretty good and creepy. Gave me a good first impression and my expectations rose, but then the leads enter, and the first thing that hits you are extremely hollow and stereotypical characters. The female lead is really bad and awkward to watch, and the lead guy's friend is just a caricature. The lead guy is fine, but sadly, Carrie-ann Moss is sadly just a cameo. I really wish she and Douglas Smith would be the leads, which would be far more interesting.2. The plot is all over the place. It seems like they had a good idea to begin with, but completely lost its way during production. There's no real explanation of anything, and it just makes everything pretty dumb. When you're glad leading characters are dying to stop watching them act – it's really bad.3. Clishès after clishès.... Seen it all before. The trailer was much better than the movie itself. 4. Bad special effects. There is a computer generated hell's hound in this, and it looks like something out of an old playstation game. Unless you're a huge horror nerd that just have to see it, don't waste your money on it. If you wanna see a good horror – avoid this one!

This movie came to me, recommended by IMDB, in their "Movies like this" section, as well as I'd seen it on another site as being highly rated. So, I looked it up, found it on Netflix!!✔ I then I pulled it up on IMDB and saw it had a great cast!! ✔ You have an up and coming actor who looks like a young Shemar Moore(be still your hearts ladies!), Carrie-Anne Moss, Faye Dunaway, & one of my ALL - TIME FAVORITE actors, Mr Doug Jones!!! Doug has been in SO MANY movies, like Hellboy and Pan's Labyrinth, but many people don't realize it's even him, because he's Hollywood's Master of Disguise!!! Add in Douglas Smith, who was in Percy Jackson, a favorite of my son& mine, and you have a recipe for a great movie!However, somebody didn't follow the recipe right, and burnt the cake! The Bye Bye Man is - to put it simply -a rip- off of every horror movie with a baddie that shows up when you awaken him and he comes after you either when you're sleeping or when you speak his name or something of the nature. The babadook, Nightmare on Elm Street, and there's a lot more I could name they've all been ripped off to make this movie. There's a lot of movies exactly like this going around right now. The only unique thing that I can see is that the bye bye man had a dog creature, and confoundingly enough, there's something to do with 2 gold coins which aren't really gold coins when you look at them they're silver, but apparently when they show up so does he. I say confoundingly enough because there's no real explanation in fact for pretty much everything in the movie there's not a whole lot of explanation! There's no back story as to who the bye-bye man is, where he came from, why he's doing what he's doing, why people feel that they have to kill everyone who knows his name or his heard it, it's just very bizarre! Now I'm not saying it's a bad movie, there's just so many frayed Ends sticking out there is that it's frustrating when a movie is a rip-off to begin with, but to not have any explanation as to the things that are going on, it makes for a really rough watching. Quite honestly I kept checking the time to see how much more I had to sit through, several times I considered just quitting, and that's not good. A movie should be entertaining and you shouldn't have to wonder how much longer you had to sit through a movie!Now my positives and negatives. Positives would be there's a great cast, I think they did a real wonderful job of picking who they did and the whole group was quite believable! I would have liked to have seen more out of Doug Jones, I don't think he in particular had enough time on the screen, but he sure was terrifying! That's why he always does best! The camera work was good, no complaints there! The outside of the house was quite beautiful and the yard was scenic and absolutely the kind of place I would want to live! Now to the negatives. I was trying to force myself to come up with positives cuz there's just so many negatives. And this is going to be hard to try not to give things away cuz I don't want to have to say their spoilers here. The script was just awful. It was a total rip-off of the genre, could they not come up with something more unique? At the very least put some unique spin on it so it's the same genre but in a way that no one's ever seen it before? I think the writers ought to be flogged! The house was just unbelievable. It was beautiful outside, but inside it was a disaster! It had the same wallpaper from the 70s? Things were falling apart and in extreme disrepair? It just didn't match it made no sense! Plus, from the outside you could see a bunch more rooms then when you're showing the inside, there aren't as many rooms as there should be by looking at the windows from the outside! So somebody did an oopsie! Some of the plots smaller side plots we're ridiculous too, like the librarian going home and killing her children, why would she do that? She didn't have to tell her children the name, and I don't understand this whole thing of If someone knows the name you have to kill them. Why? Why do you have to kill them? I can understand the desire to kill yourself, but why do you have to kill someone else? Again another proof of this whole plot being absolutely ridiculous! I think someone just wanted to throw together and move you real quick to try to make a bunch of money. It fell flat on its face. This movie is a stinker! That's why I only got three stars! And out of those three stars, all three of them are only there because of Doug Jones! I would give this movie a0 if it weren't for him!Now I'm not saying don't watch the movie, because I honestly think that some people might enjoy it, and if you don't try to think, and just watch it and go on with your life, maybe you'll get some kind of enjoyment out of it that's up to you not me but to me it was pretty awful because I had to force myself to watch it. Best of luck if you attempt to watch it!

reviews.review_title: SPOILERS: Don't think it, don't say it, don't watch it.
reviews.content: I was forced by IMDb's regulations to give this one when I wanted to give it zero. Now, I know there are a great many reviews on here that blather on about what was so awful about this garbage film so I won't go into unnecessary detail.So what did I find so horrid about the Bye Bye Man? In short, everything. The acting was terrible, the writing was bad, the story wasn't thought through, and, most importantly, the bad guy's backstory was not explained at all (thus leaving the audience confused in addition to angry that they wasted their money.) Even the movie's editing was choppy and jarring. There is not a single redeemable feature to this movie and trust me, I wanted to find one.The Bye Bye Man? Should have been called the Shouldn't Have Been Made Man.

Horror is for horror fans. You cannot judge a horror film with the same merits you judge any other genre. The goal of horror is simply to set up a premise, make the characters semi believable and then throw in your "monster" to rattle the chains and kill off all but one survivor. The reason horror gets the bad rap and low scores often is because fear is subjective. The bottom dwellers in scoring shouldnt be here in the first place. They dont like horror and jump on their uppity throne to stare down at those of us who do with great disdain pompously awaiting the next negative review they can set upon the horror world. BUT....
IF YOU LIKE HORROR FILMS, the BBM is actually fairly competent and great fun. There are good scares here for those who crave a good scare. But please ...those who give this film a one or two and spend hours writing their craft line..."say bye bye to this film", should go back to their joyless closed minds and await the next commercial big screen bubblegum for the brain film they so desire. The Bye Bye man is not for everyone. But those who adore the SET UP, the DEATHS and the PAYOFF will be solidly rewarded here. The formula rarely changes but horror is an art that only the true fan can love.
The Bye Bye Man is a fine little film and if you like horror it's a solid 7.

reviews.review_title: Expected nothing - but got a few scares and chills
reviews.content:
I picked this up from Pound-land on Blu Ray so I was not expecting much.The story is a pretty generic Nemesis style horror film.
Something nasty is coming for our main characters and it doesn't look like it wants to make friends.I actually really enjoyed this.
The production and direction are pretty good as is the acting.
The majority of the jump scares and creepy moments land effectively and my interest was kept right up until the end.This movie is unlikely to blow your mind but it is well made, does the job and then ends before it out stays its welcome - what more can yo ask for?

Three young friends, stumble upon a mith legend
called ''The Bye Bye Man''.
The Bye Bye Man, is very much like The Slender Man,
with very similiar pattern. Like both movies have this
modern teen horror pattern which is just so boring
and un-real.

I saw the preview on Showtime and said to myself, "ooh, self, that looks creepy, let's watch it!". My self agreed and it first was excitedly creeped out and confused. My self even chastised me for putting on a "scary" movie knowing my propensity to freak myself out at night. But then I started wondering what happened to scenes--it cuts from the middle of a fight to people in bed like they left the rest of the fight on the editing room floor. I became gradually more aware of the bad acting, and not long after that, it sunk in that the writing was pretty awful too. From there, it became laughable: lingering shots on unimportant things, undetectable character motivation, truly terrible dialogue, and a villian that just wasn't frightening. And let's not forget, one tiny section of wallpaper comes alive and growls even though there's no character there to observe it, as if the audience will feel menaced be a wallpaper dog. Seriously. That really happens, apparently for no reason. All in all, I don't anticipate any problems sleeping tonight, unless I have more It related nightmares.

**This review is based on the UNRATED version**Caught this one On-Demand last evening. I took most of the day pondering which way my review would go because this one really left me scratching my head.What started with an interesting premise, managed to build some tension, and creep you out (even if just a little) turned into a muddled, confusing mess, and left this viewer with more questions than answers. Towards the end, it just seemed the director really did not know which way to go, and ran for the hills!Another reviewer has stated he thought the acting in this movie was beyond terrible. He also said he had seen a lot of horror movies with bad acting. Really? Although there certainly were not any portrayals in here that were Oscar-worthy, I have seen WAY worse. I liked the director's idea to not reveal the villain until the end, although I will never understand what that dog had to do with anything. The director stated she considered this movie a "Greek tragedy" because all the characters were doomed--they just didn't know it.Although there were aspects to this movie I liked, the "rushed" ending just did not set well with me. As noted above, the version I reviewed is the unrated version. It lasts 100 minutes and contains nudity, simulated sex, disturbing images, and violence. Toss-up for me on this one.

In 1969, a man goes on a disturbing murder spree obsessed with anyone who is told of an unspoken name. In the present day, Elliot, his girlfriend Sasha, and his friend John move into a house off campus. Kim leads them in a seance where she goes into a trance repeatedly telling them, "Don't say it. Don't think it." It's the Bye Bye Man. Detective Shaw (Carrie-Anne Moss) investigates with the bodies piling up.The idea that the boogeyman exists only due to the stories that we pass on to each other is an intriguing one. It's an idea filled with great possibilities. Sadly, the execution is poor and any potential is squandered. The start with the flashback is fine although it could use more tension. It may work better to start with a victim's point of view. It's generally fine. The first real problem comes with Elliot. He's a douche. It's more than simple rooting interest deficiency. These young people are supposed to deteriorate with delusions and mania as the hallucinations take hold. Elliot starts as a douche and the delusions don't change him that much. He needs to start as the hero or at worst neutral. He shouldn't be a douche. The other issue is presenting the premise with an easy progression of expositions. I'm not sure how Elliot or anybody is able to figure out the movie's central premise. The lead character should be a literary expert or folklore student. It needs to be an ancient myth or connected to present-day superstition. They can't just come up with the premise out of the blue. Aside from that, this horror is rather derivative. The intensity is low. The characters aren't compelling and the young actors aren't charismatic enough to excel. The movie deteriorates into uncompelling horror action. The writer needs to go back to the draft and reconsider everything.

Everything about this film is wrong. It is terrible in every single way.
First, the writing: The three central characters are not characters. They are puppets, simply existing to further the "plot". Frankly, the dialogue is a mockery of the English language. At one point, a character says "you know I can't read in the dark, I'm not a flashlight". NOBODY TALKS LIKE THIS. The plot is derivative, and is clearly just a set up for a potential sequel, that will never happen if there is any justice in the world.
Secondly, the direction and shot composition. Admittedly, the shot composition in this film is at times, competent. However, the director seems to think that just because you put in a long shot or a tracking shot, you are the next Kubrick. Additionally, the budget of this film should not allow it to look like a cheap, lazy student film.
Thirdly, the acting: Doug Jones is a fantastic actor. Carrie Anne Moss and Faye Dunaway are fantastic actors. But even the best actors have to be given CHARACTER to act well. There are no even half decent characters in this film, only cut outs that are made even blander by the cast. This film is not a character driven piece. The actors in this are absolutely atrocious, and I continuously question how they ever got past an audition process. The main actor isn't even a bad actor in everything, there is one scene in this where he is actually pretty good. This really does show that the director of this film has no idea how to work with humans.
The Scares: Barney the Dinosaur is a scarier villain. Barney is creepy, the Bye Bye Man is just an excuse for jumpscares, all of which are predictable and almost patronising in their blatant. The CGI in this film is also terrible, only ever used for gore and the Bye Bye Man's horrendous looking dog. You can practically taste the pixels on that dog. It isn't scary. This film would be a lot more interesting if the Bye Bye Man wasn't called that, and if you never saw him. EVER. His presence is not creepy. It is not disturbing. It is goofy and distracting. If I wanted to watch a creepy talk guy appear in random places to scare the main character, I'd watch Sinister instead. At least the villain from that film doesn't look like a de-shelled turtle man.The constant switching of characters through the Bye Bye Man's powers ISN'T CLEVER. The internal logic of this film does not hold up at all, in fact. Several times, the viewer is left wondering "so what can the Bye Bye Man actually do?" and "why are there seven Elliots?". There is no thought or effort put into this film. None. None whatsoever. I'm actually offended that this was released in cinemas. Nothing matters in this film. There are no consequences for anyone or anything. The main characters all die? We don't care! There is nothing to make us care.This film is actually one of the worst films ever, people complain about horror films these days and I can see why when they produce such garbage like this. The only reason this film gets more than 1 star is because it is so much fun to sit back and mercilessly mock this film. I have legitimate hatred towards the people that directed and wrote this film. It's not suspenseful. It's not scary. It's not interesting, and most importantly, it isn't purposeful. This film has no point to make. Maybe there's an allegory for mental illness in there somewhere, but this is a worthless film deserving of no praise from anyone. The people who made this should be ashamed of themselves.Michael Trucco, you're better than this.

The Bye Bye Man is a wonderful movie. Something that prevents people from liking movies is constantly making comparisons to other films and characters that are not universal. For example, we compare movies we love (The Conjuring), to others that are released and if the movie doesn't compare to the story or have related characters, we thrash it and claim it was bad. Not every movie needs to spell everything out for the viewer and assuming that the movie doesn't explicitly state where the killer is from or the circumstances of its background, we assume that it's dumb or doesn't "make sense." I think we should have standards and judge movies based on their merit and acting, but we have unreasonable expectations of what those are. Please give every movie a chance.

reviews.review_title: The Bye Bye Man is going to get you
reviews.content: Three college friends find themselves in considerable jeopardy after a local boogeyman figure known as the Bye Bye Man (Doug Jones in full-on spooky mode) begins stalking and tormenting them.Director Stacy Title relates the enjoyable and engrossing story at a quick pace, ably crafts a creepy and unsettling mood, generates a good deal of tension, takes time to develop the characters, and maintains a fairly grim'n'gritty tone throughout. The solid acting from a capable cast helps a lot: Douglas Smith as nice guy Elliot, Lucien Laviscount as the easygoing John, Cressida Bonas as the perky Sasha, Michael Trucco as Elliot's concerned older brother Virgil, Jennal Kanell as foxy psychic Kim, Carrie-Anne Moss as the hard-nosed Detective Shaw, and Faye Dunaway as the reclusive Widow Redman. A neat little movie.

reviews.review_title: the low ratings are a result of an industry vendetta
reviews.content: I'm a horror fan. Any horror film rated 5 or more is descent. I disregard all that are under. This movie was a rare exception. The first review gave a 1!? What? Did he date and have his heart broken by one of the gaffers or perhaps one of the actors? Did this person somehow get screwed? Casting couch? Ouch...OK too far. Bye-Bye Man deserves a 5+.

reviews.review_title: Don't pay it, don't watch it
reviews.content: A few friends and I had the pleasure of screening this movie yesterday and my summary title of the review is kind of the first thing that was said as we walked out of the screening. Don't pay it, don't see it. It was more comical than scary in my opinion, I think the movie could have gone a handful of better directions to actually be considered a horror movie. The CGI dog was pretty bad. The premise was good, but really didn't go anywhere. I wanted to like it but I expected horror, not finding ourselves laughing among ourselves. The acting was OK, seemed forced in some areas. I did like to see another movie filmed in Cleveland.

reviews.review_title: What movie did these whiners watch?
reviews.content: Some IMDb reviews are really obviously written by people involved in the making of the film trying to boost its ratings. After having seen The Bye Bye Man, I am now convinced that also the opposite is true: some of these bad reviews must have been written by competitors trying to steer viewers away from this solid film toward their own teams' efforts.My rating of 8 is probably biased upward because I personally love the overlap of psychological and supernatural in my horror. Probably it only really deserves a 6 or 7, but the concepts and execution are leagues better than most of the films of this genre that make it to the theater, and certainly better than at least 80% of the horror on Netflix.I'd been wanting to see The Bye Bye Man ever since the previews came out. It looked interesting, as previews often do, but of course we've all seen previews that make the film look way better than it ends up being. Especially as a horror fan, I have developed the ability to control my excitement and be ready for intriguing looking films to be awful. The Bye Bye Man far surpassed my moderate expectations. Of course it's not perfect. (How many perfect films have you honestly ever seen?) There were a few bits I rolled my eyes at. But it's still easily one of the best horror films I've seen in the past five years.Maybe people are forgetting what horror means. Maybe they want nonstop blood, guts and boobs.If you are a fan of actual horror, at least give this one a try. It's obviously not going to be for everyone. But it definitely deserves more than the 4.8 that it has at the moment I'm writing this.

Real Horror Buff here. These reviews are down right silly. It seems the people reviewing this movie are into horror, but slow annoying horror films where nothing happens, long and drawn out stories, nothing that will make you jump out of your seat. When I read a review from someone that says "this movie sucks" and then compares it to The Haunted Castle, that's not really a comparison. You can't compare movies from yesterday to today.
