I expected a B grade horror flick. Instead, I got a well-scripted, well-directed, gripping horror. It has one of the best opening scenes in a horror film I've seen in a long while, and the rest of the film lives up to this early promise.I'm a horror buff and can happily recommend The Bye Bye Man. It's freaking cool.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as the rating / reviews lead you to believe
reviews.content: I've seen a lot of horror films in my lifetime, and this one is neither among the best nor the worst. If you're a fan of the genre then I'm sure you've seen a lot of absolutely unwatchable films - this isn't one of them. Sure, it has some minor issues, but overall it's completely watchable. I won't go telling all my friends to watch it, but I'm not sad I wasted my time on it either. In one word, MEH.

I think the idea is unique and interesting, but it's ruined by bad direction and effects like something out of a TV show. It's so bland that trying to guess the tone is impossible, it's not serious because of all the dumb, unintentionally hilarious moments like when this guy in the opening shoots all these people.Bad Things:It sounds scary enough, but what ruins it is 1) It's shot during the day, so all hope at a scary setting is lost, if it was shot during a sunset or at night, then it would be forgiven. 2) The whole thing is shot in one take, so the already mediocre actors look even worse at their job. If they just shot the scene normally the whole scene would look and be acted more competently. 3) The writing is awful, so even if they did all the things I suggested, the scene would still be bad.The effects look like a TV show or something, I don't know what the budget was, but this got released in theaters and it looks like a TV miniseries or something. If you were to come across this on Netflix, it would fit right in, you would think this was another cheap Netflix horror movie, that's the level of quality were talking about. Especially the dog thing, it looked like a PlayStation game.The acting is pretty bad, it's not the actors fault, the garbage script they were given didn't really help them.It has a lot horror clichés like jumpscares, psychic goth girl, seance and magic thing that really works, scary library scene, claims to be based on a true story and so forth.Good Things:The idea is good, I think the idea of an entity that spreads through thinking about him and knowing his name is pretty scary, they should have chosen a scarier name than the Bye Bye Man though.While the acting is bad, there is one scene with Trinity from the Matrix (I don't the actors name) and this one guy who looks like Dane Dahan where the acting and writing are pretty solid. I really like that scene. I think the Dane Dahan guy can be a good actor when he's given good material and good direction and I guess that scene they accidentally got good acting.While all the digital effects are bad, the practical effects are solid.Overall, I think if the idea was given to a more competent person, this could have been a decent horror movie.

There are a few horror movies that are good to rewatch now and again, because they're fairly interesting and have something about them. I would put this one in that category.Never boring, the plot moves along nicely. The main characters work well and the overall acting isn't as bad as other reviews have said (I must admit the girlfriend is not going to win an Oscar though). The bye bye man is an effective nastie with a few tricks up his sleeve.Some have said this is a teen movie, maybe because I'm early 40's, I didn't know if they meant it has teens in it (most by the numbers horror movies are) or if it was a 12 rated made for teens horror, thankfully it wasn't the latter.Here we have a supernatural baddie vs a small group of friends and a police woman trying to piece it all together. Not original, but enough quality that it will certainly not be a waste of your time.

reviews.review_title: A SOLID HORROR-don't believe bad reviews
reviews.content: I watched this movie and the new Halloween tonight and I cannot believe Halloween has better reviews than this film. They should be reversed. This film has decent lighting, good jump scares, creepy scenes, and a good plot. I normally stay away from horror films with teens as main characters, but this was the exception. I watch horror films pretty much exclusively, and believe me THIS IS WORTH WATCHING, despite the bad reviews. It's no Silent Hill or IT but it is A SOLID HORROR FILM.

I tried to like this movie, I really did! But, like many of the reviews state, it's just not very good!
I have liked Carrie Anne Moss since the Matrix, but even her small part in the movie was awful.
The acting is dire, the story pointless and tedious with no explanation as to why The Bye Bye Man exists. There is nothing remotely scary about the film at all.
Honestly, don't waste your time watching this.
2/10

reviews.review_title: The Bye Bye Man review by Hogan Coad
reviews.content: I can say with the upmost confidence that The Bye Bye Man is a movie I will remember for a long time for all the wrong reasons. This is easily one of the worst horror films I've seen in a long time. As I type this review, my head is still spinning from the sheer stupidity I've witnessed. If you notice terrible grammar and poor sentence structure in this review, it's most likely due to the amount of brain cells this movie extracted from me. The film is about three teenagers who've recently purchased a creepy old house that Elvis Presley would sing about in his song "In the Ghetto". When our protagonist finds a nightstand with "The Bye Bye Man" sketched on the inside, paranormal occurrences begin to happen all over the house. Basically if anyone says or thinks "The Bye Bye Man", he and his poorly rendered CGI Rottweiler will kill them. I realize that was a terrible synopsis, but it was a terrible movie and I just want to tear it apart now. The acting in this film is absolutely dreadful. All of the written dialogue and onscreen chemistry resembled a film you would see on the sci-fi channel on Tuesday night. The plot is equally terrible if not worse. For example, there's a scene where the main character wants to research the bye bye man to find out what exactly he is. Well since the film takes place in 2017, he naturally goes to the library.....the library. There is literally a shot earlier in the film displaying an iMac. Apparently the film wants to be set in the 50s. There's also a recurring nuisance in which the characters say exactly what they're thinking while they're performing an action. And by "recurring" I mean literally all the time. I also think it goes without saying that we never learn anything about the bye bye man. His story, motive, high school years, favorite ice cream flavor at Ben & Jerry's, none of it is revealed. On the bright side, the terrible acting, scares, and effects can be so terrible that they're laughable. If you ever find yourself hanging out with a bunch of friends and you're in the mood to just ridicule a god awful film, this is definitely one to check out. But if you're looking for any other reason to watch it, the best advice I can give is don't see it, don't think it.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as these reviews say
reviews.content: This is a solid B movie. There are great moments that are creepy, the story is decent, acting isn't as bad as everyone is saying. There are a lot of great actors in here.Lucien Laviscount who's in the Snatch series, Michael Trucco from BSG! Douglas smith does a great job. It was creepy but had some eh moments. I'd def watch a part two!

Watched this with zero expectations, just hoping to see a relatively good halloween-flick like Scream, but damn this movie really was bad. Very poor story with extremly bad acting.Dont waste your time here, move on and find something better.....period.

This movie is NOT that bad! I actually quite enjoyed it and it truly creeped me out during certain parts. People are too harsh on horror movies. Watch it for yourself and then decide if you agree with the 4.3 rating.

reviews.review_title: Not that bad. Worth a watch
reviews.content:
I went into watching with low expectations (due to average score on here). Its not brilliant and a must see but definately not as bad as it made out to be.
Not a bad story. Acting could be better by some (especially Elliott's girlfriend) but if you generally like horror movies its worth a watch. Odd few jumps and some parts a bit comical wierdly.. Certainly better than some of higher budget movies ive seen at the cinema.
Rated only to get the score higher.

Words cannot even describe how bad this movie is. People might defend it for some obscure reasons and that's fine. But don't be fooled into thinking this might be one of those "misunderstood" movies that people complain about just for fun. It really is that bad if not worse!

Though I don't entirely disagree with the reviews I've read, I do think that some understanding about the bad acting should be considered.Ninety nine percent of horror movies are always going to fall into the realm of B movies or worse. This is primarily because of derivative storytelling and average actors.If the actors were any good they would be getting better roles. These types of movies seldom give the actors anything they can really sink their teeth into.The girlfriend played by Cressida Bonas, this was her debut and really, what could she do with the part she was given? It's basically a walk through just be yourself role. There was no challenge to it.It's been said that a good screenplay brings out the best in A+ actors, A+ actors can take an average screenplay and make it seem better than it actually is because of their talent, but a bad screenplay will make even the best actors look bad.If you're a fan of horror it's watchable. If you're going to watch it like a movie critic you'll be disappointed. Movies regardless of genre are subjective. What one likes another will dislike.For example, I know people that absolutely love Sharknado. I think it's so stupid that I won't waste one second of time time watching it.

reviews.review_title: A compilation of jump-scares centered on a discount Spirit Halloween cape and a tired mash-up of ideas nicked from a dozen better movies.
reviews.content: Jerky skepticism kicks things off, but characters quickly start jumping to conclusions so they can explain to viewers a story that isn't actually happening on screen.

First of all: I've seen far worse movies than this one. Giving it 1 star would just not do the other movies justice. Yes, the actors aren't good, the story is pretty weird at times (read on!), the whole movie isn't played out great. Still it has a creepy atmosphere, most viewers may relate to the characters' emotions. In general it's your average horror flick to watch with easily creeped friends. You should just not think about it too much.The biggest failure of the movie is that it had a great back story and missed to implement the main plot:
It just never tells you who the bye bye man is! It rather tries to create another "Candyman" while it would be so much better sticking to it's origin "the bridge to body Island'.Spoilers!The actual back story is about a man who gets scorned and tormented so much, he seeks revenge, which then it turns him into a serial killer who travels through the states by train rather than being a "hallucination" that no one but Elliott, who has visions of trains for no good reason, can see.The dog is actually called "Gloomsinger", and was sewed together by the bye bye man himself to help him track his victims after turning blind himself. It needs dead bodies or it will decay. The bye bye man has no intention of turning students mad so they start killing each other. Also, why is not a single person in the movie questioning the dog who eats dead bodies?!The bye bye man is said to be pale (albino) with long hair, tattooed and wearing glasses and a hat. He's carrying a sack of organs. So it's not that bald funny dude in a scream-costume that can be seen in this movie. Also, why is no one in the movie ever mentioning that robe standing in their bedroom, turning into a vision of a hallucination of the bye bye man.Also, why do the characters never talk about their hallucinations but beat around the bush, taking about the bye bye man all the time without actually figuring out anything (like his dog, the train, the coins?) at all.The writer of the bye bye man may have misunderstood or just glanced over the original story or, and we know that's more likely, did change the plot in purpose, knowing that pseudo mythical events do buzz on most algorithms these days.
The original story of the bye bye man would have ended in plain old slasher movie.
But most of us would have loved to see that slasher movie!

Not sure about all the hate, pretty good movie. Just writing this review to try to get the rating up, as this film does not deserve the low score it currently has. Garbage name though, which I suspect is part of the reason its garnered so much hate.
I thought the acting was pretty bad and honestly kind of a stupid storyline. I don't think it's a total waste of time to watch, but I definitely wouldn't watch it again. Ending was predictable.

reviews.review_title: Finally, a psychological thriller about Emperor Palpatine!
reviews.content: I just saw The Bye Bye Man this past weekend and all I have to say is this had potential to be fairly solid but fails in almost every aspect. I went in not knowing much about this film, and I left with a lot of opinions to say the least. Let's organize this with pros and cons, because I just like to be organized.Pros:-There are some creepy moments to the film. It's nice to see a new horror/thriller use some suspense for once.-The Bye Bye Man has a ridiculous sounding name, but is a cool looking character. Props to the costume designers for that one.-A few performances were actually pretty solid, the guys who play the Bye Bye Man, Elliot, and John all do a consistently solid job.-It's obviously trying to be something along the lines of Slender and A Nightmare on Elm Street, which I think is interesting enough. I love classic horror, and The Bye Bye Man gave me feelings of not just Emperor Palpatine, but Freddy Kruger as well. He's an entity that doesn't really exist but is claiming victims through their minds.Cons:-Anything with significance is left completely unexplained. I left the theater with a lot of unanswered questions. Where does the Bye Bye Man originate from? Who the hell is the Bye Bye Man? Why does the Bye Bye Man have a dog or hellhound type thing? Why is a nightstand the most significant thing about this entity? What do these coins that keep dropping everywhere have to do with anything?-The film is only 96 minutes long, which I felt could have totally used another 15 minutes to just explain some things.-Although I was pleasantly surprised at the beginning with the suspense, it gives up on any suspense after the first half hour or so and relies heavily on jumpscares the rest of the way through to get any sort of audience reaction.-The Bye Bye Man's dog/hellhound type thing should have just been scratched on the whole. There's no explanation as to why it's there and the CGI is laughably bad.-Besides the characters I listed in the pros, the rest of the acting performances are kinda meh.-The film loses all of it's tension after a bit. Eventually I found myself laughing more than being scared.-The premise is kinda...meh. Doesn't make a lot of sense because you're not supposed to say or think his name, but how do you not THINK it? There's no real plot twist or anything to make the story interesting, the ending is a little flat and overall just didn't step out of any boundaries to be original. Basically meaning the whole movie is full of clichés.-Severe lack of transition. Remember when I said it could've used an extra 15 minutes to explain things? Tack on some establishing shots to that extra time. Scenes jump from one to another with no transition which makes the first half of the film retardedly confusing. We were a half hour in and nobody had any idea what was going on.-This was CLEARLY watered down last minute to try and fit a larger audience, nearly being rated R but released PG-13. There's a flashback in the beginning where people are getting blasted with a shotgun but there's zero blood to be found. It should have taken the chance with an R rating instead of trying to hang on to PG-13 guidelines, which probably explains why there's nothing that steps outside of the boundaries for originality.So, yes, The Bye Bye Man should have just been a straight to Netflix thing. Anybody who liked it in any sense can't give it more than a 6. I had to give it a 4, it's nice to get a refreshment of classic horror but the negatives greatly outweigh the positives. Would I watch a sequel? If it's done right and explains some origin or backstory maybe. It had the potential to be solid on the whole, but it never really makes an effort to go anywhere outside of it's comfort zone, or even explain anything that's significant to the story, not even the title character for Pete's sake.

It wasn't as awful as the other reviews would suggest. After the first scene that looks really cheap, it actually was alright. Was a bit of a cliche but I don't think it's trying to be the most serious horror film with a name like The Bye Bye Man. The acting was watchable and the storyline was interesting enough for me to finish it.

reviews.review_title: What Do You Want From A Horror??
reviews.content:
I can't comprehend the low rating. Is everyone trying to compare it to "The Exorcist" or "Poltergeist?"
That being said, this movie kept you interested. It didn't utilize cheap jump-scares and didn't go off on unnecessary tangents. I approve. Ignore the low rating and give it a try.

Not a lot of positives but I like the idea. Once you have heard or read the name, you are plagued with hallucinations that eventually lead to your death and anyone else around you who has heard the name. Evil urban legend. Not bad, not good, but it kept me watching.
Do not be fooled by the reviews! It's a great horror movie!
Actually not that bad. If you're a hardant horror fan. This is quite tame. If not, you'll probably be terrified lol. I wouldn't pay for it but free on Netflix. It's worth a watch. Enjoy

The entire foundation of this film, which is its story, is just bad. Take a ridiculously unthought-out premise and flimsy storyline, add in an amateurish script with some uneven-to-terrible acting and a godawful movie title--and the result? A pointlessly drab movie-going experience. Despite a few seedlings of interesting ideas, and one or two minor scares, this is a watered-down, bloodless and fairly scare-less exercise. The worst part, for me, is that it's totally un-smart. How and why did veteran actors Carrie Ann Moss and Faye Dunaway involve themselves in this project?

reviews.review_title: This is obviously a great movie compared to average horror movies...
reviews.content: This is the kind of movie requiring an advent into being sufficiently cultured in things such as mystery and literature. No, it's not your typical, nonsensical, thriller-alike horror fest, even though the cover might suggest such, hence the stereotypically literary acting. An horror movie might differ on the thematic approach behind it, and is not necessarily something meant to be simply "scary" for the so obviously fanatic masses, it might also be the object of curiosity for people interested in the occult, complexion of plots, or stigmas regarding the context in question. With all that said... This is obviously a great movie compared to the average horror movie! From the makers of the instant classic Oculus: Devil's Mirror movie, this masterpiece seems to enact once again plot twists worth the wondering. One of the funniest things in this movie is how, the character of another race looks extremely similar to Timbo, from the Oculus movie, adding this movie some extra ironic element and approach into it... However, it's important to beware of the nudity present within the movie and use some discretion regarding it, if necessary...

reviews.review_title: Terrible, but terribly good in a bad way
reviews.content: One of those horrible horror movies that make you laugh. Whether it's the bad acting, the boogie man storyline with a twist, the weak jump scares or the laughable kill scenes this is below average for normal movie viewers or a classic for B horror fans. Carrie Ann Moss must of really needed the money because this is not one you really audition for well maybe the other actors. The girls are cute so that's a plus

reviews.review_title: Ain't no lie, baby Bye Bye Bye
reviews.content: By far the worst thing about this movie is the title, which seems more like something from a steam game from 2011 than anything to be genuinely scared of. This entire movie is tainted by this, and removes any possibility of viewers remembering it with anything other than laughter.While this movie is conceptually decent, it fails to deliver over and over again as the 'plot' unfolds. What seems like a concept with a lot of potential for tension and lore ends up being a badly executed version of something we've seen over and over again, 'demon causes spooky hallucinations before driving its victims over the edge'. The movie seemed like it was going to give some sort of exposition or explanation of the villain, but ended up giving absolutely nothing other than what we learn from the trailer.The acting has one or two moments that pleasantly surprised me, but for the most part it was either lifeless, over the top, or just strange. If there were any reason to suggest watching this it would be so that you can witness the trip that is the acting in this movie.The movie looked good, and, with the exception of a terrible CGI dog that played no significant role, the villain and the scares were probably the most entertaining part of this movie. Doug Jones portrays the awfully named antagonist with an air of originality, and looked great while doing it.If you want to see what the fuss is about, be my guest. But don't say I didn't warn you.

I've read through a few of the other IMBD reviews and yes I see the point of the low ratings. But I thoroughly enjoyed the movie. It gave an intersting enough story and topic that kept me interested, and it had some real good pacing. I would best reccomend this movie if you want some thing better than just back ground noise but it wont blow you away.

This movie wishes to use the ethos of an urban legend style horror story (e.g. "Candyman"), but is only used as a vehicle for jump scares. 
The acting is sub-par, every character is a cookie cutter stereotype seen in every teen horror film from the 1980s onward, but poorly executed.
The story is dead on arrival, with an antagonist without any set mode of operation, and without any motive or payoff. All we know about the character of "The Bye-Bye Man" is the repeated ad nauseum mantra "Don't think it, Don't say it," but that's it. Apparently, it leads to your death, and the only way to get rid of him is to remove any mention of him anywhere. However, the only people who die are killed by other characters trying to remove any trace of the supposed villain. And in the end, when the villain actually has a chance to deliver some form of payoff...
He does nothing. 
Nothing in this film is engaging. The colors are muted, the camera work is sloppy, the special effects are not effective. But on top of it all, it's not fun. I love movies that are so bad they cross the threshold into good souly based on how much fun they are to watch. This movie doesn't even dip a toe in the waters of fun. It's all regurgitated cliches from better horror movies, and all done lazily. If there was a movie specifically made to make a paycheck, this would be it.
Its not a great movie but I've seen worse. Cressida is a terrible actress though. Shes not believable & is very mechanical. This movie has potential. Fill in the random holes & clearly a new cast.

I'm keeping this short and sweet as this film really dosnt deserve the time. It contains a VERY small amount of jump scares, in fact I counted 2 jumpscares in the whole 1 1/2 hours. It has such a ridiculously clique plot that really bored me to the point of falling asleep, LITERALLY. Also the acting is awful! It honestly felt like one of those school films made by kids. there are so many things wrong with this film, but I will be here all day - so to save the bother don't waste your time.
Dont read all these negative comments on here about this movie I believe that it was fantastic and scary!! Again dont think it, dont say it!!

Most reviewers must have sand in their vag. This horror flick may seem like it could be another throw away, but it is quite excellent. After watching, I was curious to see what else the director had made, only to find all these poor reviews.I had to write a review just to set the record straight. The movie was entertaining and moved quite well. It seemed somewhat fresh. Which can be quite hard for the horror genre. It's definitely one of the better movies I've seen this year.Good acting, well lit and an intriguing story. Worth every minute of its hour and a half length. Very creepy. It we'll draw you in from the beginning. Enjoy the ride.

reviews.review_title: It got me so scared that I couldn't say his name until four days later.
reviews.content: I want to start off by saying this might be a little bias. When I fist saw this on Netflix, it was night, the lights were turned off, and I was by myself. This reminded me of creepypastas, and I really like those.I really liked it. The chanting of "Don't Say It. Don't Think It." was really cool to me. The coins, the dogs, and the train horns were neat and unsettling. The fact that the curse of the Bye Bye Man affected everyone so easily like a virus was a really cool concept.It really spooked me, and I was paranoid for a while. I couldn't even say the name of the movie for the next four days. I watched it by myself twice, and I watched it once with my sister. She ended up hating it, but to each their own I guess.

reviews.review_title: In the first five minutes the main actor knocks on a concrete wall and it makes a crunching sound, that's how bad this movie is
reviews.content: Literally think of how little care the editors had to take to add crunching/weak wood knocking sounds in the first 8 minutes (7:40). It's laughable, I work in the industry this is a disgrace to movie making and art in general. I can't believe Netflix would pick this up.Not to mention all of the other horrible reviews. I cannot get over the fact that this man knocks on concrete and it sounds like he is knocking on a hollow, thin wood wall. Were the editors both deaf and blind? Legitimately I've been roommates with blind and deaf folks and they would never let something like this represent their name. The editing and production crew for this movie should be ashamed of the quality they were willing to put out and again Netflix should be ashamed that this is on their streaming service. reviews.review_title: IM NOT SAD TO SAY BYE TO THIS MOVIE FOREVER
reviews.content: Jeez the only thing scary thing about this movie is the quality just terrible! From the acting to the cgi it all just fell lazy and uninspired. I watched this film with my family and we predicted most every "Scare". It all just seemed uninspired to me it was unnecessarily confusing. And there were a lot of scenes in the film where there was nothing happening and I don't mean in the "wow this is so suspenseful" way the cgi and practical effects looked pretty bad to me and my family on our viewing of the film. The bye bye man is like Jason Voorhees if Jason couldn't use his machete and just stood there ominously with the power to make poeple see things and nothing else and with the bad effects mixing with this the bye bye man is almost comical. Now for the characters there all so ridiculously dumb they literally go into every trick head first and fail to come to obvious conclusions until it's to late. The acting is one of the worst parts of this really bad movie sasha's acting was particularly uninjoyable the only performance that I found tolerable was that of the character vigil. And on top of all of that I felt like there was this weird allegory for mental illness (like schizophrenia) and they even reference columbine while talking about the MC Elliot at the end like tf. Now for a personal gripe I don't how if it's just a problem with my TV but I could hardly hear anything unless it was a unscary Jumpscare and I turned it up to like 70 and ended up just turning on subtitles. But in short this movie was just bad I would not recommend.

reviews.review_title: Good fiilm to watch at home
reviews.content:
This film The Bye Bye Man was directed by a Stacy Title one of many female directors in the film industry. She is known for her films Let the Devil Wear Black, Last Supper and Down on the Waterfront. The Bye Bye Man seems to be Stacy's first horror film. "When three college students move into an old house off campus, they unwittingly unleash a supernatural entity known as The Bye Bye Man, who comes to prey upon them once they discover his name. The friends must try to save each other, all the while keeping The Bye Bye Man's existence a secret to save others from the same deadly fate.".
The Bye Bye Man consisted of many different symbols that constantly occurred. Some symbols that occurred in this film were a coin and trains. All these things in the film that essentially brought upon the demon/evil spirit. The coin could be a symbol of having two different sides of you. It could also symbolize taking chances because like everyone does as you "flip a coin". Trains where a constant symbol in this film because the train would be something those who knew the Bye Bye Man's name would see trains in their sleep. This symbolized the that he was coming The Bye Bye Man was coming for you like a train just chugging along looking for his next stop/victim.
A major motif that I found in this film that occurs in many other horror films were the steps or signs of this demon or monster. In The Bye Bye Man, some signs that the Bye Bye Man was coming/haunting coin flip, trains, dreams, the dog, hallucinations, "don't say it don't think it", psychic, and Ouija board. In this film, the main characters Elliot (Douglas Smith), Sasha (Cressida Bonas) and John (Lucien Laviscount) moved into this house on near their college campus. Once settled Sasha began to hear the sound of a coin flipping and doors slamming shut by itself. She was later told that the sound of the coin flip means that the Bye Bye Man is coming. The trains like mentioned before were another sign that the Bye Bye Man was coming because you see it in your dreams. Then that is another sign you start having weird dreams that just keep getting realer and realer every time. When finding out the history of house and Bye Bye man the students were told that if you hear or see the dog the Bye Bye man is also near the dog is the Bye Bye Mans evil side kick. Hallucinations is another motif that occurs in this film the Bye Bye Man starts to get in the student's heads and makes them see things that aren't real and going after what their weakness. There is a saying in this film that is repeated "don't say it don't think it" which is how you somewhat control the Bye Bye Man haunting you. A major motif that appears in this film is a psychic and use of Ouija board these two things are known for antagonizing the evil, awakening the evil and making the evil stronger. Many films like Nightmare on Elm Street, Babadook, Conjuring, and many more. All these films talk about signs and how the evil entity will appear and haunt you. For example, in the Babadook the story explains how the Babadook would haunt you. In the Conjuring the "demon experts" explained to the family the steps of how the demon attacks you and begins to possess you. The Bye Bye Man did the same it explained how the Bye Bye Man appears.
The Bye Bye Man was overall a decent film. It was good for it being somewhat of a low budget film. This films budget was approximately $7,400,000 this is kind of low budget for most films. The only thing that really bothered me about this film was the special effects. There were many parts of the film where the demons pet dog would be walking or eating people, and it looked super computerized. If I were to rate this film it would be a 6.6/10.

I find it very comical for those who find this a "good" movie. It is absolutely horrible and the main 3 actors are even worse. Just a horrible film all around. No one is capable of making good horror movies anymore.

I only have 9 minutes to review this film so I will do my best. To begin, it is troubling to see a film like this, with decent production value, end up being such a huge disappointment. The cinematography for this film wasn't groundbreaking but it can at least be considered 'solid'.As for the premise itself and the painfully unrealistic script, the same cannot be said.The Bye Bye Man is so devoid of anything that can be considered even remotely realistic. The plot is simple - which isn't necessarily a bad thing - but the plot points that fill out the storyline are just...dumb. The circumstances that motivate the characters to act are questionable in and of themselves and the responses that the characters have to their issues are boring and, once again, unrealistic.I can forgive a movie with wooden acting, stilted dialogue, and embarrassingly stereotypical characters if it is, at the very least, fun. Sadly, The Bye Bye Man is the farthest thing from fun. I will admit that I laughed at some of the serious parts of the movie, but not in an enjoyable way. Half of the time I found my eyes rolling into the back of my head because of corny dialogue or weird, unmotivated character actions.All in all, this film was just...not fun, not smart, not entertaining, and hardly original. If 2017 was the year when horror movies took a nosedive in artistic value, this was the film that helped to sink the ship.3/10 extremely generous stars...
You can get my thoughts on this flick on my podcast! The episode we did for this movie is located at https://open.spotify.com/episode/4P4t0izBW14yxGKkOu58nn?si=8e9a6b83aa3c4d05

It's probably gotten more scorn than it deserves because of the unbelievably silly name of the titular antagonist: The Bye Bye Man. Would it be scarier if he was called The Adios Amigo or The Later Alligator?  Probably.

The Bye Bye Man has an amazing concept it is a malevolent spirit that can be summoned simply by speaking his name only once, when that happens, it gets into your mind and causes its victims to see things that aren't really there as a way of driving them to madness and murder. The Bye Bye Man clumsily mashes together elements from better horror films, adding up to a derivative effort as short on originality as it is on narrative coherency or satisfying scares.

The Bye Bye Man comes off as a poor-man's antithesis to The Ring. Stop me if this sounds familiar, but a supernatural murderer with extraordinary powers and a sneaky subtle way of getting to you places the "trigger" for its curse in a very convenient location that then spreads like the flu and claims lives slowly after a few days of psychological torture, ending with people turning on each other and one person finding out The Truth On How To Win thanks to the previous victim knowing part of The Truth On How To Win, only for it to not matter and for them to lose anyways. No? That's totally unique? If you say so. The actors look uncomfortable throughout the film, and not just as their characters. This film also carries that whole psychological trick where after you're done watching it you think, "Oh man.. what if this happens to me?," and it succeeded in that department, which is the only reason it gets 1/5 instead of 0.5/5. The Bye Bye Man features a scathingly childish name which it could have turned into some creepy child-spread curse, but didn't because then it'd be too close to The Ring (as if it wasn't already). The development for the supernatural killer is nonexistent, we learn nothing about him, he's just The Guy That's There. The cliches are all here, too. Protagonist finds a creepy piece of paper that says spastically "Don't think it don't say it", then reads the name, and what does he do? Well of course, he runs off and tells as many people as he possibly can, even after his damn ghost-parents tell him not to. Ultimately the movie ends with stupidity. A librarian found run over, holding a bloody knife, and her kids have stab wounds? Clearly it was the guy that HIT her, not her, and is the girlfriend holding a pair of bloody scissors tightly in her hand? Well, woah, that's gotta be the main protagonist's fault that his best friend has scissor wounds, too. This movie follows no logical progression, and will leave you frustrated.

Quite frankly, The Bye Bye Man was a disgrace to the horror genre that simply offended the very core values of horror fans by even existing. The acting was horrendous, the premise was unexplained, and it teemed with the worst cliches of the old horror slashers that modern watchers would laugh at today. I would almost call this movie a comedy if the very production of the movie was not so terrible that I laughed at the existence of this low-budget, low-quality, pathetic excuse for a horror film. I cannot find the words to truly express why you should not waste your time watching this movie. With as many times as the movie said, "Don't think it. Don't say it." I would recommend you follow their advice. Don't think about this movie, and don't speak about this movie. It's simply better that way.

The Bye Bye Man is a scary film. The concept of finding curse and it latches to you until you come up with a solution was definitely an interesting horror story. And the jump scares caught me off-guard while watching the whole film. However, it seems that its story is a combination one or two other horror Hollywood films that we have watched already. The story makes me think that it is possibly be inspired to other horror movies like Candyman (1992) and Nightmare on Elm Street (1984) because of its similarity or likelihood to those films. I wished the film elaborated more background about The Bye Bye Man and not just about a link to its past as show in the movie. The film mainly focuses on the jump scare tropes and horror tension of the film while it suffered a no solution ending which was hard for some viewers to swallow.    

But on a good note, some other parts of its story still has originality like the concept of The Bye Bye Man itself. And its story is kinda haunting like it lingers to you even after watching it. Another was the compelling performances of Douglas Smith as the lead character Elliot. The supporting characters also gave some stellar performances like Carrie-Ann Moss and Faye Dunaway.
If you are thinking about watching this movie, watch It Follows instead. If you already saw It Follows, then go ahead.

This movie is none of those. It's not even funny bad. It's just boring bad. I've watched it twice now. Both times I could barely stay focused on what I was watching. I think the cheesy writing and dull plot would have gotten away with their shenanigans had the cinematography and atmosphere at least looked like they were trying to pull you in... but they don't.

Direction: Stacy Title
Cast: Douglas Smith, Lucien Laviscount, Cressida Bonas, Doug Jones, Carrie-Anne Moss, Faye Dunaway, Jenna Knell

The Bye Bye Man is an interesting film. The film begins in 1969 as a man with a shotgun walks around his neighborhood and murders anyone who said 'the name' that should not be said. Fast forward to the present, college students Elliot (Douglas Smith), Sasha (Cressida Bonas) who is very tasty , and John (Lucien Laviscount) move into an off-campus house. After they discover the name The Bye Bye Man, things start to go bump in the night and they feel a presence around them. The more they think about the name, the stronger the presence grows. So, they start hallucinating. Those hallucinations lead to distrust, misunderstandings, and irrational fear. 
First and foremost, I really liked the concept. The hallucinations aren't particularly frightening, but I thought they played out well. They help create a sense of doubt in every scene. The film was also paced well, never dragging its feet. And fairly well acted.There is some suspense here. It's not a nail-biter, but it shows some effort. 7/10

It makes it so Faye Dunaway will now have to specify that interviewers cannot bring up "Mommie Dearest" or this flaming sack of dog shit disguised as a movie.

The worst one was when he appeared in a window reflection. The first act was a bit slow, but I highly recommend The Bye Bye Man if you enjoy bad movies.

Look, not every movie can be a winner.  I get that and I understand it.  Unlike the philosophy some Americans would have you believe, there's nothing wrong with coming in second or third place.  There really isn't.  There isn't anything wrong with placing fourth either.  There is a problem, however, if you're 150 out of 200 competitors.  I mean, really, there's nothing wrong with that either, but there's nothing to be proud about either.  Having said that, in most cases, if you're a professional athlete, then that lack of success might motivate you to work harder so that, next time out, you place higher and higher and higher.  But, unfortunately, when applying this to horror movies, it just doesn't work.  Once a movie has been released for an audience's consumption, there is nothing that you can do.  I mean, technically speaking you can, with director's cut if, by any chance, the director wasn't satisfied with the cut that was released in theaters.  But, really, you only really get director's cuts with major movies.  I doubt The Bye Bye Man is gonna get a director's cut ever.  Nothing is impossible in this world, but I'd be willing to put money on that.  I don't know what, if anything, Stacy Title would have done with this movie.  For all we know, she's satisfied with the end result, thought I find that highly unlikely.  Also, she directed this movie based on a script written by her husband, so there's that.  That's really irrelevant.  But, let us move on, shall we?  As if it wasn't obvious to you by now, I did not think that this was a very good movie, like at all.  In fact, I'd have to say that this was very bad.  If I'm being honest, and I always am, I only really ended up watching this on a whim.  I was actually gonna watch Don't Knock Twice and when I searched for that movie on Amazon Prime, this one also came up.  Both were available to me as a result of my Showtime week-long free trial.  I saw this and I was like 'fuck it, I'll watch this'.  Simple as a that.  I really had no intentions of watching this (since the Edge of Seventeen is still on my watchlist and Cronenberg's Rabid, which I may watch tonight).  It was just something I decided to do on an impulse.  That impulse turned out to be dead wrong.  DEAD WRONG I SAY!  I will say that the movie starts out promisingly enough.  Larry, played by Leigh Whannell, in 1969, shoots and kills eight of his friends, all of whom knew about the existence of the Bye Bye Man, before killing himself.  He does this to contain the knowledge of the Bye Bye Man, who makes you see things that aren't there and, generally, drives you nuts, so no one else has to suffer through this.  If everyone who knows about the Bye Bye Man is dead, he can't continue to haunt them.  Anyway, this is information we get later on.  The point I'm trying to make is that I felt that the movie starting with Larry murdering all these people was the right way to start this off.  Of course, however, the PG-13 limitations put a bit of a damper on that since you can't really get a sense of how horrible these murders were.  These people were shot with this shotgun at, relatively, close range.  So the lack of blood was very inconsistent with wounds associated with shotguns.  That lack of authenticity really hurt the movie.  And it was laughable because, later on, you see more of Larry's murderous rampage and he shoots this teenage girl.  She's slammed into the wall and she falls to the floor.  Larry moves into the kitchen and you can see the wall the girl slammed into and there's, literally, the smallest blood splatter you will have ever seen.  It's absurd.  For fuck's sake, just take the R-rating and be more gruesome.  At least it'd give us SOMETHING.  Regardless, that's neither here nor there.  Moving on almost 40 years later, these three teens (Elliot, his girlfriend Sasha and his best friend John) move into this house.  I don't know if it's Larry's former house and, honestly, I don't really care.  Anyway, they use Larry's nightstand.  Elliot finds these coins in the nightstand and this writing.  The writing says: don't think it, don't say it and a name.  That name is, of course, Bye Bye Man.  Because, really, if you're not trying to say a name, the next logical step is to write it down so, even if you're not saying it, you're thinking about it since you're seeing it.  Great fucking logic there, my dude.  Whatever.  So this happens and then strange shit starts to happen to them and this psychic lady who was there when Elliot uttered its name.  Yawn, am I right?  First things first, this is a very derivative horror movie.  It's like Freddy Krueger and Candyman wrapped into one, except not nearly as good or clever as those films.  Secondly, the Bye Bye Man itself is, literally, one of the least scariest horror villains that I've ever seen.  I had to be redundant there with the 'least scariest', because that's how ineffective he actually is.  Like what is he even supposed to be, honestly?  He wears this pajama robe with the hoodie on.  And, underneath that, he's wearing clothes you would wear to sleep.  Like sweats and a regular shirt.  His face is disfigured.  There is that, but the fact that his face is covered up for most of the movie means that he's the least threatening horror villain I've seen in ages.   I mean the guy does have what seems to be a hellhound and that might be the only 'scary' thing about him.  The first scene the hound appears in is actually decent.  But once you get a more detailed look at him, the CG on the hound is laughably bad.  Speaking of that, there's this transition from one scene to another where they show the wallpaper from the hallway, I'm assuming.  The design of this wallpaper is of this deer and a doe.  So the head of the doe slowly transitions to that of the hound who turns to look at the camera.  Like, honestly, I don't know if this was intended to be this way, but this effect was so terrible.  It was honestly just dreadful.  If this was done in earnest, like who did the wife/husband duo think they were fooling.  This can't have been planned as a legitimate scare because it's so openly awful.  I mean, I'll be frank, it made me laugh.  But it made me laugh because of how someone though that this might be a good idea.  Oh no, the killer wallpaper.  I should be SO afraid.  Give me a fucking break.  There's also this scene later in the movie, where the hound walks toward the camera and this hound is massive, but the steps he takes are so small that it's a bit of a dissonance, seeing something so menacing take such dainty steps.  I suppose now we have to move on to Elliot, Sasha and John.  I mean, do we really have to?  I guess no review about this is complete without talking about these insufferable assholes.  With the villain making you see things that aren't there or not letting you see things that ARE there, this leads to the inevitable love triangle.  Or at least the villain manipulating Elliot's mind to see things that aren't there.  And, honestly, I couldn't have cared less about these people to invest in this bullshit story.  There's an incredibly awkwardly shot sex scene where John is giving it to Sasha doggy-style but the way the camera shoots them makes it look like they're not even in the same planet.  This movie is so fucking bad, honestly.  All of these are incredibly poorly-written characters.  There's nothing to any of them.  And Sasha, oh boy, it's time we talk about Sasha.  She sets feminism back about 1000 years.  She's completely fucking useless.  She's either looking concerned, sick, coughing, crying or sleeping.  Jesus, what a fucking weakling.  Not to mention that she contributes nothing of value to the narrative.  I mean, yea, she's the one that brings Kim (the psychic) to do a seance.  But, other than that, the only thing she does is just take up valuable time and space.  Well, really, maybe not valuable.  She might be the most useless female character I've seen since Bella Swan.  But, at the very least, as awful as those movies still are, Bella finally started fighting for herself and her weird, CG daughter.  Sasha is even more useless than a damsel in distress, if such a thing is possible.  Elliot and John are just unlikable assholes.  Carrie Anne Moss, inexplicably, is in this movie.  I imagine they cast her because they were probably planning for this to be so successful that they would get a sequel, so they needed to plant the seeds in this movie with her character to, possibly, continue on.  The very notion that this movie would get a sequel is laughable to me.  Also, Faye Dunaway is here.  She needs that machine from Eternal Sunshine so she can erase the memories of ever appearing in a movie so terrible.  The reality is that this, if handled correctly, could have been an exploration of mental health issues told through a horror lens.  Of course, the idea that this movie could tackle such heavy objects adeptly is, also, highly laughable.  The climax is...ok, but obviously not nearly enough to save this.  There's a, almost, a clever twist in that you think it's finally over, but Elliot's niece (who's name I can't remember and I don't care) was outside their house during the climax (with her father, Elliot's brother).  She was roaming around to pee or something.  After Elliot kills himself and they're riding home, the girl tells her dad about the writing in the nightstand.  He asks her what the writing said.  And she replied that she can't see in the dark.  Actually, we'll get to what she actually says in a bit.  So I was like, ok, that was pretty decent.  And this is where we'll end the movie, you think it's over, but it's not, but it is because the girl couldn't see in the dark.  Nope, they fucked themselves out of a conclusive ending, but it is what it is.  Time to get into what Elliot's niece actually said.  She said, and I quote, "You know I can't read in the dark.  What do you think I am?  A flashlight?" and she said this with a smirk on her face like she was so proud of herself for having coming up with such a zinger.  And never have I ever wanted to kick a child in the face as much as I did at that moment.  Other than that, it was such a CRINGE-WORTHY line.  I cringed so hard that I thought my face was permanently gonna be that way.  No woman would ever love me, for having such a hideous face.  It's not the only cringe-worthy moment in the film.  Everything with this little annoying asshole of a niece is terrible.  Just like everything about this movie, outside of the beginning, is terrible.  Having seen this movie and experienced its awfulness, it's no surprise to me that Stacy Title and Jonathan Penner have not gone on to become a successful filmmaking duo.  With movies this bad, you just wanna put them on a rocket ship and send them to the moon where they can keep making their shitty movies for themselves.  I hated, almost, every single second of this.  I'd rather have pink-eye than suffer through this again.  Umm, yea, don't watch this.  A few laughable moments don't make up for the overall hideousness this movie gladly provides to you on a silver platter.

I think La La Land has a shadowy culprit to blame for the big slip-up at the 2017 Academy Awards where it mistakenly was declared Best Picture before the rightful winner, Moonlight, was crowned. Actress Faye Dunaway was the one who spoke aloud the infamous slip-up, but I think she had something else on her mind. She was so preoccupied with trying NOT to think about the Bye Bye Man that she wasn't fully paying attention to the moment. Fortunately, Moonlight got its rightful due. Unfortunately, The Bye Bye Man exists as a horror film and Dunaway within it. This is a movie whose mantra is "Don't say it, don't think it," all but begging to be forgotten.

If The Bye Bye Man had been the film it appears to be in its opening scene, we might have had an effectively unnerving horror thriller. We watch in a single long take as a distressed man drives home, mutters to himself, and takes out a rifle and systematically kills every person who admits they said "it" or told someone. He goes from person to person, pleading whether they told anyone, and it's always yes. Then he moves on to kill that person, asking them the same question. It's an effectively chilling scene and a fantastic way to open a horror movie. And it's all sadly downhill from there, folks. The rest of the movie is a stupid thriller with stupid teenagers doing stupid things.

Any power the Bye Bye Man has as a concept, a mimetic virus, is wasted as a goofy Boogeyman knockoff with vague powers and intentions. Apparently, one of the insidious side effects of the Bye Bye Man is his ability to cause erectile dysfunction. After the first night he-who-shall-not-be-named is named, two of our college students talk about trying again and how "that" never happens to them, all but implying the Bye Bye Man was a sexual detriment. Another weirdly defined power is that the Bye Bye Man causes his victims to see hallucinations, though sometimes they're nightmares like maggots crawling out of eyeballs, and other times they're fantasy, like a naked friend beckoning for a lustful tryst. One character hears disturbing scratching noises and then visions of people standing buck naked on train tracks (the amount of brief nudity made me recheck that this received a PG-13 rating). "We're all losing our minds at the same time," a character bemoans at the 41-minute mark. At one point, the Bye Bye Man sends himself as a GIF, knowing how to reach millennials. I don't understand why these kids don't accept that if they see something horrific it's probably false. They know the Bye Bye Man is terrorizing them with their fears and yet they fall for it every time. When you're talking with someone and all of a sudden they start seeping blood from every orifice, maybe that should be a clue. If Elliot (Douglas Smith) knows he's afraid of his girlfriend sleeping with his best friend, then shouldn't he doubt the voracity of seeing them together after the malevolent force with evil visions has entered his life? What's the point of scratching "don't say it, don't think it" as a preventative measure? That calls more attention to the forbidden item. It's like in Inception, when they say, "don't think about elephants," and invariably that's what you're going to think about.

If the Bye Bye Man can make people say its name, then why isn't it doing this all the time? Why all the hallucinations to drive teens to kill themselves? That seems ultimately counter productive to Bye Bye Man business. Any businessperson will tell you the key to expanding your outreach is through happy customers. Fulfill these people's wishes and then come to collect later. I can write an entire proposal for the Bye Bye Man to shore up his business. He seems to be doing everything wrong. If the goal of the Bye Bye Man is to spread its name/message, along the same lines of self-preservation through proliferation like the haunted Ring VHS tape, then it needs a more straightforward approach. Let these doomed teenagers know their nightmares will end if they bring in an additional however many new victims. Alas, the Bye Bye Man is painfully unclear (it even has zero references on the Google imitator search) and just another boo spook.

Even for horror movies, the characters can be powerfully boring and meaningless. The entire premise is a group of college kids moving into a house that used to be owned by the crazy guy in the opening flashback. They each take turns seeing things, hearing things, and doing things, some as mundane as scribbling without their direct knowledge. The plot is in a holding pattern that requires characters to repeat the threat over and over. The only setup we have with these characters is one house party so we don't exactly know what they're like before they start going crazy. Much of their hallucinatory confusion could be mitigated if they just communicated with one another. "Help, Friend A, I am seeing [this]. Is that what you are seeing as well, Friend A?" It leads to a lot of rash actions for supposed friends. Elliot even refers to his friend as a "jock," which is a term I don't think anyone out of high school says. When the police suspect Elliot of foul play once his friends start dying, he is acting completely guilty. He begs Carrie Anne Moss (The Matrix) not to force him to say a certain name or else her kids might be in danger. That sounded like a thinly veiled threat. And then the police let him go!

The mystery of the Bye Bye Man's history is the only point of interest in this story, and even that has its limits. The librarian (Cleo King) is hilariously hyper focused on delivering exposition. She even knows the protagonist on a first name basis. I think she lives to tell people about this one weird event in the school's history. She even calls Elliot on the phone! The librarian reaches out to him, saying, "I've had some strange dreams ever since we talked." She then asks if she can come over to his house later. What kind of relationship does this person forge with students? Dunaway is featured as the wife of the opening killer, and I just felt so sorry for her during every second on screen. She deserves better than this. Somebody go check on Faye Dunaway and make sure she's okay.

The Bye Bye Man is a horror movie that's so bad it can be outlandishly funny. It starts off well and deteriorates rapidly, abandoning sense and atmosphere for jumbled scares. There's an extended bit during a climactic dramatic moment where a father has to convince his daughter to pee out in public. I felt so bad for every actor involved. I'll even spoil the ending, which made me howl with laughter. A little girl talks about how she saw a table with some writing. "What did the writing say?' her father asks, and oh no, here we go again you think to yourself. Then a second later the little girl says, "Daddy, you know I can't read in the dark! What do you think I am, a flashlight?" My God, that moment should have been followed by a rimshot. This half-baked movie opens up a lot more questions than it has the ability to answer. What is the mythology of this character? What's with the constant train imagery? Why does the Bye Bye Man have a pet dog? Why are the coins a significant part of its Bye Bye motif? And always, if it can simply make people talk, why isn't it doing this all the time to spread its name? The Bye Bye Man is fun bad but oh is it still bad.

Nate's Grade: D

As the title would suggest, The Bye Bye Man is about a group of teenagers who are terrorised by the aforementioned creature whose name seems to bring disaster to anyone who knows it. This film starts with a bit of a bang and an interesting premise but quickly deteriorates into a boring B movie style horror with a predictable plot and poor acting. The Bye Bye Man isn't the least bit scary and feels somewhat like a pale imitation of Final Destination as the characters are doomed to be killed off and the only question is how and when. Unfortunately the performances are pretty poor throughout, with Cressida Bonas giving a particularly poor performance as Sasha. The CGI and special effects are also quite poor with a weird dog like creature that looks unbelievably fake and a Bye Bye Man that looks like he's trick or treating. Overall, a disappointment and one of the least enjoyable horror films to come out this year.

What does a teen horror movie look like in 2017? Pretty much what it's looked like for the last few years, or the last entire decade even. The Bye Bye Man, while having moments of promise and even the odd genuine scare, is yet another by-the-numbers fear flick. Séance scene that ends badly, check. Randomly slamming doors, check. Flickering lights, check. Characters searching alone in the dark for the source of a mysterious noise while repeatedly calling out 'Hello, is anyone there?', check. Bad guys walking past the camera while the protagonists have their backs turned, check. Threatening writing plastered all over a wall/ceiling/object, check. It's such a shame that films like this are still being made with no innovation or originality. Building suspense is evidently too hard for the filmmakers and beyond the attention span of modern audiences, so in its place we get jump scares galore. The acting isn't good, the script is poor, the story progression is frustrating and non-sensical and the ending leaves us with the terrifying prospect of a sequel. A sequel to The Bye Bye Man? You can make your own jokes about that one. The film utterly fails to distinguish itself from the myriad of young adult horror movies where the main character act like idiots, evil, supernatural killers have no sense of urgency and everyone of importance lives in what looks like a haunted house. A wasted of time, money and what little talent it has.

"The Bye Bye Man" was a pretty weak attempt at a psychological thriller/horror, that had a lot of pretty disappointing suspense scenes, and a few too many cliches. The overall premise for the movie was pretty interesting, basically a boogey-man that terrorizes anyone that thinks about, or says its name. However, everything this movie does takes that premise and brings it down. I legitimately found this more of a parody movie than a serious horror film, as a lot of the acting, and the incredibly terrible CGI in some scenes were just comically bad. With almost every horror scene in this movie, I felt like I had already seen it before, and with the exception of some of the scenes where The Bye Bye Man uses his deception to trick people, it seemed as though it was a carbon copy of other horror movies. All in all, there was nothing that stood out about "The Bye Bye Man", except for debatable acting, and a hilariously bad CGI and animation. "The Bye Bye Man" is terrible.

The Bye Bye Man: This low budget horror film, written by three-time Survivor contestant Jonathan Penner (who also has a cameo role) and directed by his wife, is about a group of Wisconsin college students who uncover a demon who stalks his victims when they utter or even hear his name. Uh, yeah.  Don't let the brief appearances by Carrie Anne Moss and Faye Dunaway fool you -  everything about this boring dumpster fire of a film is awful - the disjointed, senseless storyline, the weak acting and the not so special effects. Don't watch it, don't see it. F

The first thing that should be criticized thoroughly before anything else in this movie is the acting. I've seen bad acting before. This takes it to a whole new level. I actually yelled out at a few points "THIS ACTING! MY GOD!"

Secondly, the writing. This is one of those "tell, don't show" movies. The characters sit around explaining things about the antagonist, rather than have the movie show us. For example, someone goes at great length to mention that saying "The Bye-Bye Man" to anyone "spreads" the evil like a virus. It would have been a lot better if we actually got to see that, rather than listen to someone explaining it. There was way too much talking in general in this movie. It really needed to be cut out.

Third... I have to give this more than one star because of how hilarious this movie was. It was no masterpiece of comedy, because it also bored and frustrated me at various parts. But good lord, when this movie was at the height of badness, it was better than most comedies. In fact, this film would have worked great as a satire if it was billed as one, due to how utterly ridiculous it was.

And what was with the girlfriend getting sick? That went completely nowhere. I thought by the end, she'd be violently ill, vomiting blood, something. None of that happened. It played no part in the plot or in character. What was the point of that?

Overall, it was funny, but not worth another viewing.

Despite the puerile name given to the titular antagonist, this film does rather well with its venture of horror. Indeed there were moments which lacked in the realm of originality( the convient information found through an internet search, or the character archtype of the wise old individual who survived the antagonist in the past). The film relied upon lesser used means to build tensions. Sure, they used jump scares, but The Bye Bye Man did not rely upon them the way other pieces from this genre so often use. Furthermore, I found the Greek symbolism (relative to death) throughout the film to be refreshing. Given the quality of current horror films coming out of Hollywood, I'd have to say this film is above average.

This is the kind of movie requiring an advent into being sufficiently cultured in things such as mystery and literature. No, it's not your typical, nonsensical, thriller-alike horror fest, even though the cover might suggest such, hence the stereotypically literary acting. A horror movie might differ on the thematic approach behind it, and is not necessarily something meant to be simply "scary" for the so obviously fanatic masses, it might also be the object of curiosity for people interested in the occult, complexion of plots, or stigmas regarding the context in question. With all that said... This is obviously a great movie compared to the average horror movie! From the makers of the instant classic Oculus: Devil's Mirror movie, this masterpiece seems to enact once again plot twists worth the wondering. One of the funniest things in this movie is how, the character of another race looks extremely similar to Timbo, from the Oculus movie, adding this movie some extra ironic element and approach into it... However, it's important to beware of the nudity present within the movie and use some discretion regarding it, if necessary...

Proper Perspective: A movie that sat on the shelf for almost two years, was re-edited from Rated R to PG-13, with a villain that is in the movie for a few minutes, a horrible title, and some of the worst "teen" actors I have seen in quite some time. Let's talk about The Bye-Bye Man...

Official Synopsis: Three friends stumble upon the horrific origins of a mysterious figure they discover is the root cause of the evil behind unspeakable acts.

Plot: Three college students move into a house and then find a dresser and then bad things happen and then the movie ends.

Take: I was warned to not watch this movie by a few critic friends of mine. I was warned not to see this movie by the bad trailers. I was warned not to see this movie the reviews. Yet, I gave Redbox a $1.50 to see for myself. There was only one question that I wanted answered going into seeing The Bye-Bye Man: Which is worse, Rings or The Bye-Bye Man?
The answer is they are both awful movies.

Having said that both movies had similar production issues. They were both sitting on a shelf for a few years, had release dates change a few times, and wholly unnecessary stories.

I'm going to use as much effort and creativity in this review as the writers, director, actors, and producers put into the making of this "film." The acting was about as close to the worst I have seen in any movie, ever. I do not want to be disrespectful, maybe the actors are sweet talented kids. Maybe the direction or edits took away from their performances, maybe, but Douglas Smith (Elliot), Cressida Bonas (Sasha), and especially Lucien Laviscount (John) were really bad in the cut we all get to see.

Screenwriter Jonathan Penner (nothing of note) and director Stacy Title (same nothings of note) have collaborated before on previous projects, and again might be sweet heart human beings, but the movie they crafted was atrocious. 

Recommendation: I don't think this qualifies as one of those bad movies you watch with your friends with a few drinks to see how bad it is. Stay away. I am sure it will be in a bargain bin by Christmas and packaged with a better movie to force you to buy it soon enough.

"The Bye Bye Man" could have easily tread into the "so bad, it's good" category, with its half-cooked lead performances and ridiculously cheap special effects, but - much to the film's detriment - it wallows in the self-serious mediocrity of exposition dumps and cooky paranoia. Truly just a mindlessly boring exercise in what a lot of modern horror directors have already grown out of - pathetic jump scares, dumb characters, and a total neglect of the established rules of its own world. Yeesh.

A silly premise.  So this is about three twenty-something year olds that move into a house in Wisconsin.  One of them finds a nightstand that has cryptic writing scribbled on the inside drawer, but underneath that is four words carved into the wood: "The Bye Bye Man".  Turns out that everybody who has ever read or heard this combination of words is condemned to a horrific death filled with hallucinations.  Will our trio of heroes be able to survive this?  Now I had already heard stories of how bad this is, and horror releases dumped out in January do have the tendency to be on the lacking side of quality.  The Bye Bye Man is no different, so horror fans: don't get your hopes up.  Now I could have forgiven a lot of this movie if there was anything about it that was legitimately scary or creepy.  If I had gotten just maybe ten minutes of chills, I would at least be writing here that genre fans should maybe rent this if they've ran out of other options.  When you break it down, the Bye Bye Man as a character is pretty lame.  He doesn't really do anything, and his one power that he has is that he makes people see things that aren't real.  He is never intimidating whenever he pops up, and all he does is sulk around in the background like an antisocial goth kid, hanging out with his CGI hell dog.  He might point at you a little bit, sure, but he never does anything that couldn't be solved by you closing your eyes.  I don't blame Doug Jones who plays the titular role, as he is a respectable working actor, he just wasn't given anything to do.  In addition to that, these are actors that don't really need to be working anymore.  Carrie-Anne Moss is the only one that gets a semi-pass for signing a bad contract, and she at least shows up.  Faye Dunaway should know better, and she is awful in a cameo role, never showing her abilities of being the capable actress that we all know that she is.  The leads are highly likely never to be seen again in future films, as they all are bad actors, even by horror movie standards.  I will say that I have seen worse, but this is a production that should have never seen the light of day, and it is the one thing that you don't want your horror movie to be: boring.

In 2016, Private First Class Joseph Allen participates in a military operation alongside United States Army Rangers stationed in Afghanistan, by assisting them in taking back a city from insurgents. Impressed by Allen's capabilities, General Shepherd recruits him into Task Force 141. While Allen prepares for an upcoming assignment, Captain John "Soap" MacTavish and Sergeant Gary "Roach" Sanderson infiltrate a Russian airbase in the Tian Shan mountains to retrieve an Attack Characterization System (ACS) module from a downed American satellite.

Allen is soon sent on an undercover mission in Russia for the CIA, joining Vladimir Makarov in a mass shooting at an airport in Moscow. After leaving the airport, Makarov, who has been aware of Allen's true identity, kills him and leaves his body behind to spark a war between Russia and the United States. Outraged by what is believed to be an American-sponsored terrorist attack, Russia retaliates by launching a surprise invasion on the East Coast of the United States.[a][32] With no evidence of Makarov's involvement in the airport massacre, Task Force 141 is sent to Rio de Janeiro to capture Makarov's arms dealer. They capture the dealer, and learn that Makarov's nemesis is being held in a Russian gulag. Task Force 141 assaults the gulag and rescues the prisoner, who is revealed to be Captain Price, a member of the British Special Air Service.[b]

Price agrees to help Task Force 141, but insists that his priority is to end the war in the United States. After raiding a Russian port, Price launches a ballistic missile towards Washington, D.C. and sets it to detonate in the upper atmosphere. The resulting EMP blast disables all electronic devices across the eastern seaboard, causing both factions to suffer but giving the Americans a much-needed advantage.[33] Soldiers fighting in Washington, D.C. narrowly avoid a bombing run of Russian-occupied strategic structures by the United States Air Force, when they light green flares atop the White House, showing that the city remains in American hands.

Meanwhile, Task Force 141 narrows Makarov's hiding place to two locations; Price and Soap travel to an aircraft boneyard in Afghanistan to intercept an arms deal, while Roach and Lieutenant Simon "Ghost" Riley raid Makarov's safehouse on the Georgian-Russian border. Although Makarov himself is absent, Roach and his team obtain vital information on the antagonist; however, when they reach the extraction point, Shepherd betrays them, retrieving the intelligence and taking it with him, murdering Roach and Ghost and burning their bodies in the process. It soon becomes evident that Shepherd is the catalyst of the war between Russia and the U.S. with the intent of generating a massive wave of American enlistment, along with defense spending and production in a time of emergency. Shepherd sent Allen to participate in the massacre, fully aware that Makarov would set America up; he also allegedly provided the ACS to the Russian forces to be compromised, informed Makarov of Allen's identity, and eventually managed to secure a blank check from the government to fund his war effort, his endgame being to kill Makarov himself and usurp the glory, thus cementing his status as a national hero. Price and Soap learn of Shepherd's betrayal, and escape a battle between Shepherd's and Makarov's forces.

Price contacts Makarov on an open radio channel, where Makarov reluctantly reveals Shepherd's mountain base in Afghanistan. Price and Soap raid the base to take revenge on Shepherd in a suicide mission; during the infiltration, Shepherd attempts to escape on a boat, with Price and Soap in hot pursuit. At the climax of the pursuit, Shepherd sails into a helicopter, but Price shoots it down as he and Soap tumble over a waterfall.[32] A dazed Soap stumbles towards the crash of the helicopter, and attempts to kill Shepherd, but is stabbed in the chest. When Price arrives and engages Shepherd in a fist fight, Soap pulls the knife out of his chest and throws it at Shepherd, killing him. Nikolai, who arrives to recover the duo, and Price evacuate Soap for medical attention.

The Bye Bye Man is a 2017 horror film from directed by Stacy Title based off of the book of the same name. The Bye Bye Man is an incredibly disappointing movie due to the admittedly interesting concept. The Bye Bye Man is one of the worst horror movies I have seen in a long time, this film isn't scary, it isn't tense and had some of the absolute worst screenwriting I've seen in ages. The film makes absolutely no sense as the script is so contradictory, for example you aren't supposed to think of the Bye Bye Man; so why on earth in one scene is the main character shouting in his car 'Bye Bye'? The acting is absolutely horrendous, to be fair the lead guy is trying and isn't that awful. The best friend however is so wooden and the girlfriend is absolutely dreadful. The directing is terrible as the film looks like it was made for about $2. The from isn't scary it's just very boring and is full of cheap jump scares and dreadful 'suspense'. This film also has some of the worst cgi I've seen in quite a while, especially the Bye Bye Man's weird dog. The only real positives are that the opening scene is semi decent and the film is destined to become a so bad it's good film in years to come. However the Bye Bye Man is a dreadful film and one of the worst horror movies I've seen in a while. D
